comment:
We bought a 2005 Mini Cooper S with 140k miles from the original owner. It has mostly been a pretty good car, but it does have a dark side. 1. Heater element in the seats burned through the upholstery. 2. The only manual release for the rear hatch is under the back seat - which is especially stupid because the battery is located in the rear on the S model. 3. Clutch slave cylinder is notoriously difficult to bleed. 4. A special tool is required to do just about any repair. 5. Electric power steering pump is located near the exhaust pipe. The pump is cooled by a fan mounted under the car, which gets jammed with road debris, resulting in pump failure. 6. The body computer, located in the passenger foot well, sometimes fails, the part is expensive, and has to be programmed by a Mini dealer.

We've spent nearly $1k trying to diagnose a parasitic battery drain, which is likely caused by the body computer...or something else.

comment:
I have owned 2 Mini-Coopers..... a 2005 'S', super-charged 6 speed, rally suspension ( rough ride ) , no frills. Spec'd it out, waited 6 months to take delivery. Went through the factory in Oxford , watched them being built. Good heavy sheet metal in them, not the tin can stuff in Japanese cars. Avoid the smaller engine, with automatic transmission: no performance.

Repairs are expensive.... eats alternators. My '05 is on it's third alternator. My 2014 Mini needs a new alternator....gonna do the work myself. Gotta take off the front end to get to the alternator....did the brake work on my '05, switched to drilled / slotted rotors... Repairs at BMW are pricey, better learn to do as much as possible yourself....

Crowded under the hood, if you have large hands, can be tight...You Tube videos are super-helpful.... Repair manuals of limited usefulness. My 2014 twin-turbo, 6 speed, sunroof, a totally different car....softer ride, much quieter, smoother.....

Best handling cars in their price range. Next step up would be three times the price.....if you want performance, go for the three years with superchargers, 2002-2005, and 6 speed trans....

comment:
IMO, some basics on Gen2 Mini's. Change the oil twice as frequently as recommended...it will save you thousands in timing chain repairs. The thermostat should be changed every 50-60k miles. Plan on it failing around that point. Also the timing chain should be changed out at around the 100-110K miles point (if you change the oil frequently). Do the thermostat with the timing chain replacement, together. Lastly, as the N14 and N18 engines are DFI, be sure to use higher octane fuels. I prefer to run with premium (98-100), to minimize carbon build-up at the intake, over time. For these engines, an aftermarket oil catch can will also help minimize carbon build-up at the intake.

If you buy used, make sure to have the car checked out by a qualified professional and insist on seeing the maintenance records. The frequency of oil changes (full synthetics) being a key indicator as to the health of the engine.

Other than that...I find the Mini to be a reliable car that is extremely nimble and fun to drive. I have both the R55 Clubman S and the R60 Countryman JCW. The later is my favorite and has proven both practical and reliable as a daily driver. Is this car as bullet proof as a Honda or Toyota...no. Is it worth the extra maintenance care? Hell YES!!!!!

comment: Scotty, your comment regarding the MG car company's choice of batteries for the MGB till '74 was uninformed and rather offensive.  The REAL reason for the twin 6 volt Group 17HF batteries was weight balance.  The MGB was designed (in the early 60's) to have 50/50 frt - rear weight distribution w/ driver, and the then - available heavy tar-case 12V batteries upset this no matter where the designers tried to place them. It was decided to fit twin 6V under the rear shelf close as possible to the car's center.  By 1975 modern lighter batteries made the twin installation obsolete and they fitted a single Group 24. Please don't slam MG for bad engineering; they knew what the hell they were doing.  I own a '72 MGB GT that does 10K mi per yr no probs, and more MGs survive today than any other classic brand ... educate yourself a bit please.

comment: Hi Scotty. That "dumb" idler pulley/friction wheel is there to help make the Cooper fuel efficient. Unlike most cars, it allows for the water pump to be disengaged when not in use (so that the car is using energy powering a pump unnecessarily). I think that by necessity, making cars more fuel efficient involves complicating their designs somewhat. I think that Mini is generally marketed to a crowd who want something fun, cute and relatively peppy, which being fuel efficient. But I'm not denying that they're generally terribly unreliable and a nuisance to work on (I've owned one).

comment: Love your videos Scotty. We own a Mini and I can attest it's not the easiest thing to work on. However, it is a 2003 and has 160k miles on it so they aren't THAT bad. :) You do have to do your research and buy the best one you can find for the year model you are looking at. There is A LOT of variation from year to year as they find new and improved ways to make a mechanic's life hell. Try removing and installing the battery box in an early car. You can replace the clutch faster than reinstalling that box! Guess I'm a masochist because despite its flaws I still like it. It requires the patience of Job and you have to be prepared to do your own work because it will bankrupt you otherwise. Not a car for the casual 'it's cute' owner.

comment: I agree!  The plastic headlight connectors on my '03 Mini crumbled to bits in my hands after about 7 years.  Mini no longer sold the inexpensive wiring harness separately.  The dealer mechanics tried to pull the headlight wiring out of a totaled Mini they had in the back of the dealership, but the same thing happened to THAT plastic connector when the mechanic tried to handle it.  So I know for sure it wasn't just rough handling on my part.  I was told I'd have to buy a whole new headlight assembly for hundreds of dollars.  So I took it to a local garage and they wrapped the broken part with electrical tape and stuck it in place that way.  Worked well enough for me to use the Mini as a trade in when I got a better car.  The headlight wiring was not the worst thing about it, but it was the part that bothered me the most after the dashboard that started to turn to glue around 8 years into ownership.  Their materials choices were unforgivable.

comment: I've owned 3 of these "new" Mini Coopers. Scotty is absolutely right. They have no longevity. You get to the 10 year mark, and everything starts falling apart. The runflats are super expensive (and the sensors break). The electronics go bad (particularly the rear bumper reverse sensors). The alternator was shot on both my partner's convertible and my Cooper before 80k miles. They're nothing like the cool little Austin Minis of the 1960s. The only cool thing about the new Minis from BMW were the supercharged variants from 04-06. That thing was a little torquey rocket, and handled like a go-kart. It's a shame, because as Scotty said, they're cool looking little cars. But don't buy one and expect it to last without significant cost.

comment:
I am a new Mini owner. I have a 2024 JCW convertible and I absolutely adore it. It's my "mid life crisis" car. I have seen many minis on the road and always thought they looked cute and peppy. I especially loved the convertible and am so happy I finally have one. It is like driving around a go kart with stiff steering and the JCW's pep is amazing. I just returned from a week spent driving my Mini through the Smoky Mountains National Park.

I love my Mini, but I'm not sure if I am a fan of the 2025. I like the sporty look of my JCW. The 2025 looks a little plain/bland. However, I do love the new round full console. That is the only thing that I wish my current Mini had. I am sure others will absolutely love the new Mini. But for now I am so HAPPY with Miss Bitty Blu. She is so much fun!

Before I bought my Mini I went through all of your's and other Mini enthusiasts videos on YouTube. I knew how to run all of the little gadgets on my car before I even bought her. Thank you for your enthusiasm and detailed information on the Minis. You are a great ambassador for the brand!

comment:
As someone who's spent far too long in the mini configurator recently a quick note on the option pack prices: the costs in the video are for the base Cooper. The Cooper S gets the Level 1 pack as standard on all trim levels and knocks ¬£2k off the price of the level 2 and 3 packs. As a result Cooper S gets Level 2 as an option on the Classic and Level 3 on Exclusive or above while the base Cooper is Level 1 only for the Classic, up to 2 for Exclusive, 3 for Sport.

Had a poke around one of these last weekends and was honestly impressed. Interior feels very spacious though why BMW / Mini reflexively insist on calling the rear bag holders seats is beyond me. Love the material switch away from leather and the fake version they're using on seats and wheel feels pretty damn good. That screen really works and after seeing a lot of the BMW bits show up in the new 1 series (and then seeing the 1 series pricing) the Cooper suddenly looks like a bit of a bargain. My only real concern is the ride as this would have to do daily hundred-mile round trip motorway commutes so have to get one out on the road sometime soon.

comment: Excellent review! Thanks for that. There's a lot I really like about the F66, but there are some things that I think are real issues for me: One, the rear of the car. I don't care for the tail lights, the black trim, and the concavity under that trim piece. Not only do these details feel out of place on the car (i.e. they aren't harmonious with the design), they're not characteristic MINI design details. I'm also wondering whose idea it was to hide the exhaust on a sporty hot hatch...that decision will never make any sense to me. Two, the rose gold trim (everywhere). I think my not-quite-young-anymore mom would love it, but it's not a finish I want on my car. To me, it makes the car look like a handbag with wheels. Three, the interior CMF (color, materials and finishes). I love the physical design of the interior. I get the references to the original MINI, and for me it all works...other than all of the conflicting patterns and colors. That clean, simple interior works best when the designers allow it to stand on its own. I've seen too many of these F66 cars, and the J01, with busy interiors. I certainly don't want blue MINI badges in a red car, for example. I also don't want every color and pattern under the sun on my seats. MINI need to back off of the CMF overload and let the interior physical design be the star...it can stand on its own. The F56 was criticized for having unnecessarily busy geometry (outside and inside), but the new F66 and J01 are still busy; they just do busy in a different way. Overall, I really like this car...I feel like it's 90% there. I'm anxious to see how MINI "fix" the rear of the car, and how long it takes them to do so.

comment:
I agree with others, the whole character of the Mini has all but evaporated. I feel a little like, since BMW were gifted the single valuable bit of Rover group they wanted - jilting Honda unpleasantly in the process - it‚Äôs like they‚Äôve gradually been ‚Äòprocessing‚Äô what was a very natural, organic product. Here we are, well over 2 decades on, and it‚Äôs lost almost all its flavour. Just imho. I mean, who knows what Honda would have done, but this is literally a Mini in name only. Maybe that works, for some people. I don‚Äôt disparage electric cars in general, not being a fan of changing gears when the car can do it for me, they have a natural advantage to me. I only know this: if EVs were the norm since 1950 say, to present-day, nobody would be able to convince a boardroom to buy or drive an ICE design. It‚Äôs inconceivable, due to the environmental catastrophe alone. But, noise, invisible toxins, etc etc, that‚Äôd blow it out the water anyway. And that, is with today‚Äôs rather wimpish batteries.

Breakthrough or not, the batteries are slowly improving anyway. It‚Äôs where we‚Äôre headed, I think the war is already over, won & lost, but during the transition, I have no beef with other motive power units, and don‚Äôt think ordinary people ought to be punished financially for keeping their purchased vehicle for a decent length of time. I drive an old Prius, and previously did indeed scoff. I literally bought it based on just two main parameters: One, it cannot have the same lousy fragile automatic transmission, all the other used cars I bought have; Two, I cannot afford enough battery power to make the car get really hot inside the cabin, after a cold or wet winter‚Äôs walk in the hills. Those two things, swung the purchase. EVs overcome the first also, but are squarely a problem for the second because nothing is much better as a boiler than a diesel or petrol/gas combustion engine. A great boiler is 93% efficient, and any old ICE is 80% efficient as a heat producer. We tend to forget only 20% gets anywhere near turning a shaft. Take care all.

comment: Good review but I hate the back and white thinking that low range = ‚Äúpathetic‚Äù and high range = good. There are plenty of us that don‚Äôt need or want electric cars with bigger batteries and therefore more range. It‚Äôs like reviewing a Lamborghini and saying the interior is pathetic as it doesn‚Äôt fit a family of 5 and 2 dogs. I‚Äôd love to see more smaller electric cars with smaller batteries but with quicker charging. If this new Cooper SE had a 30kw battery but charged at 150kW you could get 10-80% in around 10mins. That wouldn‚Äôt be an issue for long trips (if you ever take long trips) if you only had to stop for 10 minutes every 2 hours. Think outside the box. Cheaper. Lighter. Smaller. More efficient.

comment:
Many years of experience with Mini cars and as a Cooper SE 2023 owner, here's my comments and pros-cons list.
I will have to start with negatives because fairly, they ruined the iconic-retro design of their own. Throughout the 1980s and 1990s the British market received numerous "special editions" of the Mini, which shifted the car from a mass-market item into a fashionable icon because of the Retro design understanding. And since the day Mini came out with new Countryman and the new Mini S/SE. Even the 2023 Mini cooper SE has the characteristic tounches everywhere exterior and interior! KEEP READƒ∞NG DOWN BELOW. !!!

My objective thoughts and pros-cons list :
Pros:
1- Bigger battery; had to be improved because even cars like peugeot 208e-500e had bigger batteries than the previous generation Mini Cooper SE.

2- The chassis is lengthened; A longer chassis can provide more spacious interior and increases performance.

3- Growth of mirrors; I think it's counter-design, considering the iconic circular mirrors and iconic design language. However, for someone who is not very tall, larger and rectangular mirrors can be considered functional as they can minimize blind spots.

4- More options on Customization the Mini. Also great to see John Cooper Works exterior body kit so smooth...

5- More horse power means better perfomance! Great to see!

CONS; God! I'm furious and dissapointed the are too many of them! (OBJECTIVELY)
1- The black plastic artch trim has gone? Seriously? Those places especially if you live in cities will get tremendous amounts of small damages from other car doors and small physical contacts. Also where is the iconic design?

2- The taillights? What the hack you guys were thinking? The physical≈ü design had never changed since 1990's and you guys not only changed the shape, also ABOLISHED the Union jack Great Britan flag and instead put a triangular cheap material chinese looking lights.

3- ƒ∞nterior: The new generation automobile industry finds it right to express interior design in the most extreme way possible. But if we look at the cars that have reached the timeless design language. No matter what and what, you will not come across such a disgraceful interior design. The reason? The reason is that everywhere inside is made of a single material and they are trying to look as if it is a brand like Tesla. No my friend, this huge screen does not reflect the 1959 Central Speedo screen. There may be people who like it, but if everything is being completely electronic on a single screen, including the air conditioning controls, the car will be more anti-userfriendly and you will understand how useless it is after using it for a week. Also I don't think anyone has to like this stupidly designed "futuristic" steering wheel.

4- Interior buttons used to make you feel like you're in a spaceship or an airplane. This swisting and one-screen-everything buttons are definitely less charismatic than previous Mini's. More cheap material plastics being used and carpets everywhere making it like its only one piece carpet. Love to see and feels of the better quality materials on my Cooper SE! I love them.

I would be happier if I was able to see Mini brand not being gay and try to shine, wanting to be more popular, not following the stupid path started by other brands... if if if if.... Mini used to be Mini but not anymore it looks like. It doesn't feel like it. You also learn from your mistakes. No simplicity = No good.

comment:
Be warned I had one of the first F56 Coopers on the road. 18 times it was it for faults, It had design flaws that still existed for the whole build life, door rubbers that rubbed away the paint, frameless windows that had to drop in frost toget in the Car till your regulator goes bang at ¬£400. My Coop was off the road for a month waiting for a part after a display failure ( Curtesy 5 series for the duration) Rattle that still today remain that they could never find but could hear. They found the fuse box didn‚Äôt have screws so rattled, wiring went across the dash underneath that shouldn‚Äôt that rattled on a central vent under the windscreen. The light and button unit on the roof inside had loose screws rolling about and the cables were not how they should have been. It was around 14 months of the car in and out and I was furious at the time.

But and this is the but I still liked the car and the way it drove when the things didn‚Äôt annoy you -so much so it‚Äôs out on the drive just now on low miles and will be Ten years old in April. It sister sits beside it a Nov 2021 build Clubman. Just not enough changes and I promised i‚Äôd never buy a MINI early in production again. Still love the brand. What‚Äôs next sadly the EV doesn‚Äôt cover the road trips i go on holiday etc and looking at various other brands even back to one of my dad‚Äôs favourite Volvo EX30 that is just a great looking rocket ship. Probably be scary what the new Coopers start at. I was at the launch of the new EV still to hit the road when it did it‚Äôs tour round the country and the sticker price ok it was the sports pack on it but was ¬£43k for a Cooper EVüò¢ Madness.

Shame it‚Äôs only a Auto box now and no side scuttles. No separate fog lights that you could tell a MINI from a distance. And really guys if you asked owners I bet 90% would say why the rear lights are like that nothing MINI about them looks more Peugeot too me or Renault. That designer guy can talk a lot of hot air right enough. Why is it like this ? because it was cheaper just say it. Why does he say it‚Äôs a ‚ÄúS‚Äù at the end surly the S and works have visible exhausts. Presentation was a bit of a train crash if you ask me does the BMW guy actually know the product or just shoved in because he seemed lacking in parts, no offence.

comment:
My 2019 convertible S was in the shop a week or so ago. Despite notorious maintenance costs, it‚Äôs a fun car, and of the car‚Äôs I‚Äôve owned, quite possibly my favorite. Anyway, the dealership gave me a 2024 loaner, while they did the work.

The new model is boring as hell. All of the mechanical controls I enjoy, from the steering, to the traditional PRNDL stick are completely gone. The dash lost all its personality, and easy switches and buttons were replaced with a touch screen I had to click through. Wanna lower the AC? Close your navigation.

The beautiful analog gages gave way to a HUD. Functionally, this may actually be somewhat of an improvement, but it‚Äôs a total aesthetic loss.

I hope my 2019 lasts forever, because I‚Äôm not trying to replace it with that

comment:
I currently own a Mini Clubman JCW 2017 and while I had it in for service on Monday, went to check out the new range of Mini's (Aceman 'old clubman', Countryman and Mini Cooper 3-door). I was especially surprised to note that externally the new Mini's have a higher window line / slab-sided appearance than the current/last generation and wonder whether this might feel claustrophobic from the inside. They're also bigger than last generation with the Countryman being only slightly smaller than the BMW X1 small suv ergo not-so-mini anymore.

I love the brand, but geez, the prices are steeper now than ever before. The Sales person also boasted that Mini now have a 5-year warranty as opposed to meagre 3-year one they used to offer. Still other makes are doing better and even though I love the performance of a Mini, I'm gonna check out the new Toyota C-HR GR hybrid. Yes, its not a sports vehicle, but its surprisingly well economical and well appointed.

comment: Forget about grieving over the loss of a manual transmission - what about the fact they've taken away the bulb we used to squeeze to inject fuel into the cylinders? And, speaking of the cylinders, where's the crank-handle on the front to get the engine started? Pressing a button is no substitute for cranking away and possibly having your arm torn off. That was true driver involvement. And on the topic of driver involvement, where's the carburettor lean/rich knob we used to pull out during the I-hope-this-works starting the car procedure? And worst of all, they've taken away the lever we used to pull to apply the wood & leather shoes to the (single) brake drum! It is absolutely a disgrace how the manufacturers have robbed us of true driver involvement. And we can no longer experience the joy of being hurled through a (non-safety-glass) windscreen at even low collision speeds! Utterly appalling. All the romance of driving has been stripped away, leaving us with only safe and efficient and totally soulless machines of transportation.

Great review! I‚Äôve got a 2017 Clubman S All4 6MT and I‚Äôve got a few observations.

The fwd Cooper S models do tend to be a bit nervous on the front end and could use a LSD as you said. However the Clubman All4 puts its power down with no chirp, and the cornering is better at high speeds than the 2 door. The Countryman unfortunately feels a bit wooden and dull.

Also the power is under rated for insurance from what I‚Äôve heard, and independent tuners have found the stock crank horsepower to be around 227, which would be right in line with your initial estimate.

Final thoughts, it‚Äôs probably not a bad thing to try the Clubman JCW to compare to this Cooper S.

comment: 2014 F56 Cooper S owner here, mine has 190hp. If you need more, go for JCW. Cooper S is more than enough in daily life. I tried the sports mode several times. Yes, it has a difference, but it's too much for the city. No way I'll upgrade to the new generation, they spoiled the back so much and returned the dashboard to the center. I'd rather upgrade to this 2023 one and spend another ten years without problems, although I'm quite suspicious about the dual-clutch gearbox, mine is a 6-s speed automatic classic. To me, MINI is about style and driving, and the Cooper S delivers its values well. Stock run-flat tires are ridiculous, especially for bad roads. Get rid of them for Michelene or Pirelli, and you will be happy instantly. I don't need a sunroof and electric seats, less things to maintain in the long run. I hope the future generations get back to the classic F56 design and will not go with the all-sensors trend. 5-doors Copper is nonsense. Clubman was good, it's a shame BMW decided to stop the production. I'd not mind having Cooper S and a Clubman at the same time. Greetings from Ukraine. Thanks to the UK and its incredible people for their help and support in our fighting.

comment: I bought my wife a 2019 5 Door, 60th anniversary Copper S, DSG equiped version. I drive a 450 bhp HSV Track Ed, with 570nm, rear drive, 6 piston 390mm AP racing brakes. Yep it‚Äôs a fantastic car, you won‚Äôt see one as they only made 150, mine is number 90. HSV spent a considerable amount of time tuning the suspension. So yep, not only does the car stop and accelerate to 100 in 4.5 seconds. It‚Äôs rear wheel drive and handles brilliantly, both on the road and on the track. Every time I drive it, I hold the alcantara steering wheel, listen to the bimodal, exhaust burble in sport and I grin, love that car! At the time the reviewers gave it 9.5/10 & I agree. After 40 years of car experience including 3 years as a passenger in a new 1973 BMW 3.0 si, 3 years in a brand new manual Porsche 928, 3 years in a 733i as passenger and driver, 10 years and 200,000 owning a 735i Sport V8, I‚Äôve owned 10 Alfas and spent 5 years selling Peugeot‚Äôs. I‚Äôve driven many many cars that I don‚Äôt own. Having said that 5 years of driving my wife‚Äôs Cooper S. What do I think? First thing, change the tyres to Michelin PS4‚Äôs, secondly the brake pads to ATE Ceramic‚Ä¶.then you have a car that‚Äôs set up well. Personally I don‚Äôt think there is a requirement for active suspension. The standard set up is great, the only time I‚Äôve ever heard rattles is it there is something loose in the car, for instance my sun glasses case did not have the press stud closed and rattled! It‚Äôs not the car, it‚Äôs your belongings! The Sport mode makes a big difference, much faster shifts from the DSG and it automatically turns off the stop start, you also hear more of the exhaust. However if I really want to drive it hard, I push the leaver to the left and drive the car manually with the paddle shifts. It‚Äôs an nicely torque endowed little engine and always feels ready to go. When you need to get on it, it goes‚Ä¶hard. I smile driving this car and regularly. Sorry don‚Äôt agree about the Mini magic, I think this current Mini is the best Mini by a mile! My wife and I love it and for what we paid, we think it‚Äôs a bargain! Nothing better than cruising in summer either, roof open, Harmon Kardon cranking, sun glasses on, you shouldn‚Äôt be able to have so much fun, then pull into the a tight car park at the local Malvern Central in our case and we can park with ease‚Ä¶.do our shopping then head back out for the fun trip home. Our daughter often tells us to take the long way home! We feel very fortunate to own and drive the cars we do! I‚Äôve been seriously surprised at how good this Mini is, I don‚Äôt think we are the only ones, Mini sells close to 300,000 cars a year!

comment: I had two three doors - a 65 plate One D and a 17 plate Cooper S from new and they had more downsides than up. In comparison to other small cars, the build quality and road noise were much better than what I've experienced before but the real world performance wasn't too great - I 'd definitely get a JCW if I wanted another because it needs an LSD - it really struggled for traction off the line yet calling a car with <200bhp a 'hot' hatch in the 2020s seems almost a joke. The steering was utterly lifeless and the ride abysmal on patchwork British roads. The space in the front was good but as a result, fitting adults in the back was not really viable and the boot is miniscule. And yes, I could've got a bigger car if I wanted more space but these things occupy the same road space as, say, a Fiesta which are vastly more practical. I don't know how BMW messed up the packaging so badly.

comment: I really enjoy your take on the cars that you review but felt compelled to comment on your views regarding the safety of classic MInis. It is a commonly held view that they must be unsafe  but times were different when they were made and they dealt with crash safety in a different way. I know this from experience as my nieces classic Rover Mini Coopper was hit by an BMW E46 at high speed when it was over taking on a blind bend. It took the front end off the Mini but she walked away without a scratch. It may have had no no crumple zones or air bags , and the accident was horrific,  however It's light weight meant that it was knocked out the way and the shape of the shell gives it strength and the cabin was not compromised. She may have been very lucky but 2O years on she still has its replacement , a run out model Cooper S PAC , and daily drove it until very recently as it was outlawed due to the low emission regs in Edinburgh.

comment:
We have a 21 plate four door cooper s, and im a bit dissapointed in it. It has 18 wheels on pirelli p zeros, most of the year you cant put your foot down because of a lack of grip, which can be fun? But not when your trying safely overtake another car. The steering feels dull to me and the brakes are not consistent and hard to predict with. We have the manual which seems to have a very heavy flywheel attached to it, so the engine doesnt feel as lively as it should for a small car, but in sport mode it rev matches on the downshifts which is great! It also has the adaptive dampers and i can confirm that in scotland it is equally uncomfortable in all three modes. I think if i was to choose betweek taking this and my diesel mondeo out for a spirited drive, i would take the mondeo unless it was very warm.
Biuld quality though, unlike older minis it hasnt started rattling yet, although it was deliveres unfinished. And i agree with all your comments on interior, its really nice.

comment: My wife has a 72 plate Cooper S. You mention you got some wheel spin. I too notice this on spirited acceleration. The cure is to turn on DSC (Dynamic Traction Control). One would have thought it would have been on by default but it is not. Apparently DSC (Dynamic Stability Control) allows for sone wheel slippage/spinning to aid stability. The manual does not mention turning on DTC for "spirited" driving, but it does recommend it for driving in snow, on gravel/loose ground or when using the launch control (not tried the launch control, but the traction control works well).  To turn it on you need press the DSC button; Traction is then displayed on the dash. and the DSC OFF light is on. Pushing the button again turns both the DSC and DTC off, press it once more to turn the DSC back on. DSC is automatically turned  on if there is a puncture or cruise control is selected. Oh yea and it is a fun car to drive. They used to have pops and bangs on the early ones but they stopped that with these, but I find the exhaust note is quite sporty when using the performance.

comment:
Still sitting with one of the first F56 Coopers on the U.K. roads factory ordered new to my spec. Think it was the fourth or something registered. While at the beginning it had its build quality problems (it was in 18 times for faults and fixes and failures) probably my fault getting such a early build some of the rattles from day one have been my friends now after almost ten years of ownership, you learn to live with them or they will drive you mad. As a good friend and fellow MINI owner used to say buy the next gen when the ‚ÄúWorks‚Äù comes out. Fun to drive the three cylinder turbo engine one of the best engines MINI have used.

The price of all cars has gone through the roof why the Car granted on low milages is still with me. For a while it actually probably went up. Would I pay ¬£25-30k for a Cooper - nope regardless of inflation. The first gen GP engine noise was glorious the sound of the Turbo spooling up. Boot is not too bad I do road trips and holidays no problem. My high spec Cooper (sorry a lot of ticked boxes) was just over ¬£18k in 2014. The Car sits beside a 21 plate Clubman that‚Äôs on 70k miles company Car. The inside of the third gen is a nice place to be.

I specifically asked for the sport button because I go on driving holidays, trust me it works you just haven‚Äôt had the car for a long enough drive in the highlands. I pulled away following friends thinking my Car was broken, something just not right and remember about ten miles after a lunch break I hadn‚Äôt put it in sport mode. Will it light up the front tyres if you don‚Äôt watch - Yes.

I‚Äôm sure the new second gen electric will be fun to drive as well.

comment: Jay I own a 2012 Mini Cooper S R56 second gen with the N18 1.6 litre turbo petrol Peugeot BMW Prince engine. It is a well specc-ed up version with the Hartman Kardon system and all. It is superb. And honestly its engine sound and exhaust burble is very addictive. Especially on the overrun on a nice curvy downhill stretch of road. It‚Äôs a 6 speed Automatic Torque Converter gearbox with Manual mode. The paddle shifters are a delight as is the Sports Mode. Remember our operating conditions in India are very much harsher than yours in England. Normal Tubeless tyres work much better here than Run Flats. So I have Michelin Pilot Sports 4 tyres on my car. My car is still a treat to drive. Its proportions and size are absolutely on point vis a vis the new F56 3rd Gen. Sad to say that in my considered opinion the upcoming 2024 4th Gen is very ugly and bulbous. It is not a Mini any more, it is a Maxi. And you re perfectly right about these designers messing about with its looks and appearance and design just for the sake of messing about with it. Totally unnecessary.

comment: I had a 66 plate cooper s diesel with the automatic as a company car. It was a great car, comfy on the motorway and sporty enough on the twisty bits. The dealer though was horrendous. They just wouldn't service the car. Amber warning light comes on, and they said they could book it in, in 12 weeks time. Red warning light comes on, dashboard warns "do not drive the car" and they still cant service it. Mini breakdown rescue service have to come out and service it on my driveway. It then had to go to the dealer for a firmware update (which they couldn't do for 12 weeks), and they kept the car for 3 days just to update the firmware. This happened every time the car needed a service. The built in electronic service log built into the car however showed that service had been carried out much more frequently than it actually was. If it had been my car, I'd have started taking it somewhere else, but as a company car the lease company insisted that it go back to the same dealer. If you're ever thinking of buying one with a full dealer service history (especially if that dealer is Williams Manchester), be aware that the service history may be completely false.

We have a 2017 Cooper S manual 3 door. my youngest learned to drive in it in normal mode and my wife and I drive it in sport mode. Lovely inside, but little room in the back seats - but with the seats down I can fit our two big dogs in comfortably for them. All we've done to it is swap the rear lights to the Union Jack lights (they look so much better) and added a CarPlay / AA box behind the dash - and it now looks and feels modern too!!!

Oh and no creaks and cracks even after this long - but plenty of pops and bangs in sport mode....

comment:
I absolutely adore my '15 cooper. British Racing Green (best colour), with the 6AT and 3 banger. Its a total hoot to drive. Twitchy but confident, light on its feet, and the 3 cylinder has shockingly decent torque and grunt to it.

Sport mode transforms the car. Steering is much heavier, and throttle response is much sharper. As well, the exhaust note changes slightly and shifting up gives off... GTi burbles? My only gripe is, unsurprisingly, the 3 cylinder has very little aftermarket. It's a sweetheart of an engine, but if you want options... you better get an S.

comment: Excellent review. I owned an f56 cooper S with the JCW pack and I agree fully with the "competent" description. It didn't really feel like the previous R series models at all, which is a good and a bad thing. Then I got a JCW F56 and that's really worth the extra money if you like a sporty car that makes you grin a lot hahah.  The 8-speed gearbox is better and thrilling in sport mode, the brakes are way better, the electronic differential makes it way better off the line and cornering while doing higher speeds, the adaptive dampers are a must, etc.  For most people the S would be enough, but from the performance side  it feels really limited from factory to leave room for the JCW. The S is a competent car, but the JCW feels like a MINI should without losing that added refinement the F series has.

comment: The Mini is definitely worth the asking price. I have a 2023 Mini Cooper JCW convertible in Rebel green / Chesterfield Malt interior with diamond quilted seats - and it looks very sharp. It's shorter than a Miata yet it seats four people with no problem. It can also fit into a small garage and tight parking spots. Additionally, it has plenty of leg and arm room and the top can open like a sunroof or full top-down convertible. The driving experience is as good as it gets as well. It handles like a go-kart, and the Dynamic suspension easily soaks up the potholes. The fit and finish is also top notch. No other car even comes close at that price point. Worth every penny.

comment:
Couple things that seem a surprise in your review:

-My 2017 Cooper S had 19x bhp out the door, tho I have an NM power module which gives it a little more. Surprised to hear the later gen 3 models have 17x bhp.
-Also surprised to hear your opinion on Sport mode. I find it's night and day with the throttle response, and outside of bad weather, I always use it. I have a manual tho, so maybe that's the difference there? Either that or another change over the past 6 years.
-I also get tons of exhaust burbles with throttle lift off in 2nd and 3rd gear. I think those are increased by being in Sport mode and the addition of my NM power module.

comment: I have a 2024 Mini JCW with 8 Speed auto.  My first Mini.  I absolutely love this car.  Has every single option except radar guided cruise control or whatever they are calling it.  My only regret is that I did not buy into the Mini brand earlier. I traded a 2021 GTI SE Manual for this Mini and I could not be happier.  The GTI while more practical, had no personality whatsoever and was a bore.  The rev hang between 1st and 2nd was not tolerable.  Been driving manual cars since 1988 and the GTI manual made me very unhappy.    I also had a 2012 GTI with DSG and much prefer the JCW 8 speed auto.  My favorite setting in the JCW is mid mode with the Auto in Sport.  Great combination.  The Mini feels like a tank.  Well put together, fast and comfortable.   The ride is certainly firm even with the dampers in mid mode...its not for everyone.  My wife doesn't enjoy it.  I think the handling is outstanding on the Mini.  I also have a 1983 911SC and quite honestly, get more enjoyment (at least at the moment) driving my Mini JCW.

comment: The newer minis are so uninspiring. It's really sad to see the decline in what is a MINI since the first revival designed by Frank Stephenson. These (the R50 - R53 models) were a masterpiece in design, putting everything that made the original so great into a modern and speedy package. This first generation was so good in terms of looks and feel that BMW has simply been unable to beat its lovabilty to this day. Each generation since has only been an increase in bulk and a decrease in character, now to the point where you scratch your head and think how on earth can this be called a MINI? A brilliant example of a failure of brand identity. It is understandable that newer designs have to be larger due to safety regulations but coming from a manufacturer which is famed for its compact look, these are a joke. The only positive of these ugly behemoths is how great they make the classic & R53 look in comparison üòÇ

comment:
Why does the modern Mini Cooper with its new 3 cyl turbo engine deliver such poor fuel economy compared to the latest Kia GT Line turbo 3cyl Picanto?

It's something that Mini simply haven't got right.

Mini should have developed a 1litre 3cyl turbo engine with Mild Hybrid for their Mini Saloon range.

I had a Suzuki Swift 1litre 3cyl turbo with Mild Hybrid before I switched to a Mini Cooper this year.
The Swift returned phenomenal fuel consumption figures - I regularly got 55/58 mpg & last year on holiday, I was registering 66mpg.

My new Mini Cooper struggles to get above 48 mpg even with careful driving.

Suzuki can teach Mini a thing or two about engine technology, thats for sure.

comment:
I have had the Mini Cooper S Sport Island Blue 21plate for 7 weeks now & I‚Äôve loved driving it. Very responsive, great fuel economy, comfortable (for me anyway) & found it fun too drive. It puts a smile on my face whenever I‚Äôm driving it, reminds me somewhat of the VW Golf VR6 I had many years ago. It‚Äôs probably a bit of a midlife crisis choice, kids are all grown up now so no need for an mpv or suv.

Only down side I found was my last car had Apple Play where as unfortunately the Mini it‚Äôs an optional extra. To get that you have to buy the ‚ÄúComfort Pack‚Äù, then if you want SatNav you have to pay for that as it part of (obviously) the ‚ÄúConnected Navigation Pack‚Äù. Then there is the ‚ÄúComfort Plus Pack‚Äù also the ‚ÄúConnected Navigation Plus Pack‚Äù & not forgetting the ‚ÄúDriving Assistance Pack‚Äù. Then the list just keeps carrying on through accessories or kit you can add, visuals, safety features it feels somewhat unlimited stuff you can buy so you get the car you want. But this also comes at a massive Premium & hits your wallet hard.

The inside needs a total redo, it‚Äôs awful- the big circle needs to revert back to an analog speedometer with tach inside the Speedo and analog fuel, temp gauges towards bottom of circle. With that stupid rectangular screen removed from the circle they can put a very large digital display in front of the steering wheel with nav, audio etc and do something unique but still acknowledging Mini history. The engine/motor also needs a refresh, too expensive for what‚Äôs offered and since it‚Äôs 2021 it should use an electric motor to help engine by default to add power, efficiency and low end grunt. BMW started out doing something interesting with the Mini brand years ago but it‚Äôs been neglected for a while now and used as an easy cash cow, entire Mini lineup is depressing

comment:
i've got a 2020 version and i quite disagree with this review, on the handling for instance mine it's on rails, probably big difference is the JCW package i have (on a standard Cooper) on 17'', etc. and haven't tested a million cars recently but i am very happy with, especially when switching on SPORTS mode where everything is more stiff.

One point i agree with is that the tyres can get noisy, but that depends on the pressure, if you use the insanely high recommended pressures of 2.8 - 2.5 or even 3.0 bar they will be quite noisy, just use something lower and it's much better. Plus it also depends what tyre brand you use. Stock ones can be noisy indeed.

just my 2 cents.

comment: BLAHHHH. I loved MINI before they ruined them in 2014 with the introduction of the F56. 7 years later and it has no more power, no more torque, no limited slip differential, costs a fortune, still has the ugly fish mouth front end, and those stupid Union Jack taillights look like clown car lights. The R53 and R56 S/JCW were so much fun to drive. The F56 cannot even touch the old models' excitement, exhaust note, or quirkiness. The B48 engine also is a bore compared to the old N18. The old 1.6T pulled hard from idle to redline, whereas the B48 feels flat above 5000rpm and BMW has put their horrible warble through the stereo to cover up the actual engine note. It's also really strange that in 2021 you cannot get blindspot monitoring, cross traffic detection, lane keeping assist, etc. They also got rid of the real adaptive dampers. BOO! MINI needs to go back to basics and throw the F56 in the trash. The braking is also atrocious, as Mat saw. For the price you could have a Golf GTI or Golf R.

comment: My 3 door 2019 Cooper S also has a petrol particle filter but still retains the usual 192HP. The 211HP JCW tuning kit however was discontinued in 2018 sadly. Why the newest Cooper S is down to 178HP I don't know but unlike the 192HP cars the new ones will overboost not only torque but also HP. So peak performance of the new model can actually go past the 192HP/300Nm of the previous model years. Regarding comfort & road noise the wheels do really play a big role. With 18 inch wheels it's quite noisy, but the comfort is ok. Firm yes, but in a good way. With 16 inch wheels the car is a comfortable as any other and road noise is much better than with 18 inch wheels. The seats and seating position is great for my 186cms even though it's a small car. The car in the video has the fake engine sound from the loudspeakers. Comes with the Sport-Mode. Stay in Mid-Mode or don't get the Driving Modes at all and you'll be free of the fake sound. The natural sound of the car is actually quite nice.

comment:
I work at a dock and drive these at work, loading them on ferries bound for the continent. The worst parts about them are they are wildly uncomfortable over even minor bumps (way worse than my 2019 Fiesta ST daily!) and have an appalling view out the cabin. comment:
Are you sure it doesn‚Äôt have the auto rev matching? At least through 2021 all models with the manual did, including the Cooper model. My 2019 does and there‚Äôs no way to turn it on/off unless you turn off all the traction and stability aids (in which case the auto rev matching is off). Not sure if MINI made changes with the LCI2 in 2022, however.

Anyway, the Cooper model is very underrated. It‚Äôs lighter than the 4-cylinder Cooper S model, with most of the weight savings over the front axle which is always good for turn-in and handling feel. And the 3-cylinder has a more unique exhaust note than the 4-cylinder, too (4-cylinders are a dime a dozen in the car market). With some aftermarket finessing of the intake, exhaust, and ECU, my 3-cylinder MINI is making quite a bit more power than it did stock and quite a few people have complemented the sound. I also like being the underdog üòà The only thing I really don‚Äôt like about the Cooper is the manual transmission. It‚Äôs innocuous enough in general (and is very closely related to the 6-speed manual in the Cooper S model), but it has really tall gearing, unusually tall gearing. It‚Äôs clearly geared toward fuel economy. The 6-speed manual in the Cooper S has much more closely spaced gearing.

Going on 6 years since I bought my 2019 Cooper and the car has been a blast and has not had a single problem in all that time, just regular maintenance as recommended by MINI USA. Hope to pick up a new JCW when the new models are released later this year, but I don‚Äôt plan to get rid of the Cooper.

comment:
I drove the new electric Mini on Saturday for 30 minutes. It was in JCW trim in grey with a red roof. It‚Äôs absolutely fab - lovely chunky steering wheel, brilliant interior and it‚Äôs plenty quick, too.
The interior electric sound effects are great and really make it feel sporty, especially when it‚Äôs in Go-Kart mode.
The overall quality of the car was impressive. The boot, though was small - ok for a small trip to the shops but don‚Äôt expect to get a full weekly shop for 5-people in there.

comment: I'm onboard with virtually everything the designers envisioned. I love the minimalist interior, fabric surfaces and circular LED display. My previous Smart Fortwo had the mesh fabric dash and it was always a pleasure to see. The exterior is fine evolution of the Cooper aesthetic and all the cues are nicely refined. I'm dismayed the electric sunroof went away so I hope MINI has a convertible in the works. Nonetheless, the accent lighting along the sides of the pano roof is a nice touch. In the future, I wouldn't mind seeing a variable brake regen paddle shifter to enhance the driving experience. One pedal driving is fine, but a little hand/foot coordination would raise the engagement factor. Otherwise, awesome machine. üôÇ

comment:
There's 3 Minis in our House.
I have a new Mini Cooper to do the shopping in, I have a Mini Roadster that we use for days out.
And my wife has a Mini Coup√© that she uses to visit her relations & we use for UK Holidays.

TBH, looking at the new Mini as illustrated here doesn't fill me with any enthusiasm to rush out & buy one.
It's too similar to the models we already own.
And I notice that they have done away with clocks in front of the Driver.
A very bad idea....
Every Driver wants a clock directly in front of them to check speed & other important information.
The large central clock is not an adequate substitute.

And that new Dashboard they've put in.
It looks a cheap cost cutting substitute for the ones we're used to.

So NO, NO, Mini, the interior of the new Mini is awful compared to the old ones, the new Mini has a very cheap cost cutting look about it.

comment: As an owner of Mini Cooper SE I am in shock. I love my car and I thought I will never move from a Mini. Seeing this is disheartening. The renders looked good, but the reality is quite different. The materials look incredibly cheap. No metal buttons, no leather with the cool stitching pattern, everything is a a cheap fabric (which gets dirty easily and hard to touch, I can not stand it in a Polestar) and cheap plastic. Moonroof is useless if you can not open it, the convertible effect is gone. No center display with the navigation, only the hideous piece of plastic aka Head up display, which had to be disabled, it's so distractive. All the premium feel, cute lines and fun are gone. And a cherry on top, it's build in China. Thank you for making it impossible to continue to be a Mini owner. I am going to switch to another brand when the time comes. Shame.

comment: It‚Äôs too feminine looking. I own a Mini R57 S with a 6 speed manual & what I love about my car is with the right accessories it can be transformed from a girlie car to a hardcore man car. This new one doesn‚Äôt do that. The manual transmission, plastic wheel arches, side scuttles, hood scoop, center mounted exhaust are masculine traits & they‚Äôre all gone. Even the interior looks more shopping boutique which is not the look any real man want in their ride. Minis aren‚Äôt family cars. They‚Äôre not built for practicality or to make sure car poolers can commute comfortably. Minis represented the epitome of personal fun, drivers cars for males & females. No it wasn‚Äôt suppose to be a pure boy racer but rather a slight upper scale, European handling go cart. And now it‚Äôs a generic foreign sub compact along the lines of a Fiat 500 or a GR Yaris, something it really never really competed with. It‚Äôs a shame how a bunch of pencil necks can screw up something that their loyal followers want for market trends. I predict Mini will go under in 5 years.  It‚Äôs a shame.

comment:
EV‚Äôs

So, why don‚Äôt they sell ‚Äòem? Very simple, people aren‚Äôt as stupid as they think. The main players in the automotive world have been part of the con from the start. Since the EV idea started, they‚Äôve been ramming it down our throats that lithiums and cobalts and nickels, together with their oxides, phosphates and titanates as with all the mumbo jumbo required to confuse the general public into thinking that batteries are soooo expensive. Sure, mining is expensive, so is drilling for oil. It‚Äôs just that if you sell lots of it the cost ratio drops considerably. To add insult to injury THESE THINGS HAVE NO ENGINE AND NO GEARBOX, the two big-budget outlays in the industry. On the back of this, combustion engined cars have seen their prices steadily and artificially increased well beyond inflation rates to ‚Äúmatch‚Äù the EV‚Äôs.
And so we have it. The traditional affordable model which until relatively recently was selling for twelve thousand, and its electric counterpart priced at double - remember: same chassis, no engine, no gearbox - then the former pushed to twenty and the electric model, which should cost half, i.e. six, is a ‚Äúbargain at ‚Äúonly‚Äù twenty two.
If ever there were a modern version of the emperor‚Äôs new clothes, this is it.

comment:
Remember when the GR Yaris was first brought out only a few years ago and some people balked at how much that cost? I know that was expensive but it had so much changed and redone that I understood why; this Mini however, I know it's electric, but it's still unreasonably expensive for what it offers.

I'd rather save the ¬£11,000+ and have a Hyundai i20N which has similar performance; sure that has flaws and won't be as cheap to run as the electric Mini but it's hard to ignore that massive price gap. What applies to the Hyundai also applies to the petrol powered Mini.

Also to bear in mind, adding options that push the electric Mini's total OTR price past ¬£40,000 also means even bigger car road tax bills since electric cars are going to lose the benefit of not needing to pay for road tax next year, which would likely be around ¬£600 a year (it's ¬£190 flat rate at the moment, plus ¬£390 for cars over ¬£40,000 for five years, for a total of ¬£580 for this year only, which is definitely going to go up as it has done each year for both fees).

comment:
I hope some real Top Gear guy reads this detailed comment. Many years of experience with Mini cars and as a Cooper SE 2023 owner, here's my comments and pros-cons list.
I will have to start with negatives because fairly, they ruined the iconic-retro design of their own. Throughout the 1980s and 1990s the British market received numerous "special editions" of the Mini, which shifted the car from a mass-market item into a fashionable icon because of the Retro design understanding. And since the day Mini came out with new Countryman and the new Mini S/SE. Even the 2023 Mini cooper SE has the characteristic tounches everywhere exterior and interior! KEEP READƒ∞NG DOWN BELOW. !!!

My objective thoughts and pros-cons list :
Pros:
1- Bigger battery; had to be improved because even cars like peugeot 208e-500e had bigger batteries than the previous generation Mini Cooper SE.

2- The chassis is lengthened; A longer chassis can provide more spacious interior and increases performance.

3- Growth of mirrors; I think it's counter-design, considering the iconic circular mirrors and iconic design language. However, for someone who is not very tall, larger and rectangular mirrors can be considered functional as they can minimize blind spots.

4- More options on Customization the Mini. Also great to see John Cooper Works exterior body kit so smooth...

5- More horse power means better perfomance! Great to see!

6- More head room in the back is good, but there's a trick that they removed the second sunroof from the back and extended the front sunroof to have more space for the back seat passengers.

CONS; God! I'm furious and dissapointed the are too many of them! (OBJECTIVELY)
1- The black plastic artch trim has gone? Seriously? Those places especially if you live in cities will get tremendous amounts of small damages from other car doors and small physical contacts. Also where is the iconic design?

2- The taillights? What the hack you guys were thinking? The physical≈ü design had never changed since 1990's and you guys not only changed the shape, also ABOLISHED the Union jack Great Britan flag and instead put a triangular cheap material chinese looking lights.

3- ƒ∞nterior: The new generation automobile industry finds it right to express interior design in the most extreme way possible. But if we look at the cars that have reached the timeless design language. No matter what and what, you will not come across such a disgraceful interior design. The reason? The reason is that everywhere inside is made of a single material and they are trying to look as if it is a brand like Tesla. No my friend, this huge screen does not reflect the 1959 Central Speedo screen. There may be people who like it, but if everything is being completely electronic on a single screen, including the air conditioning controls, the car will be more anti-userfriendly and you will understand how useless it is after using it for a week. Also I don't think anyone has to like this stupidly designed "futuristic" steering wheel.

4- Interior buttons used to make you feel like you're in a spaceship or an airplane. This swisting and one-screen-everything buttons are definitely less charismatic than previous Mini's. More cheap material plastics being used and carpets everywhere making it like its only one piece carpet. Love to see and feels of the better quality materials on my Cooper SE! I love them.


5- WHERE IS THE SCOOP? I CAN'T SEE.

I would be happier if I was able to see Mini brand not being gay and try to shine, wanting to be more popular, not following the stupid path started by other brands... if if if if.... Mini used to be Mini but not anymore it looks like. It doesn't feel like it. You also learn from your mistakes. No simplicity = No good.

comment:
Many years of experience with Mini cars and as a Cooper SE 2023 owner, here's my comments and pros-cons list.
I will have to start with negatives because fairly, they ruined the iconic-retro design of their own. Throughout the 1980s and 1990s the British market received numerous "special editions" of the Mini, which shifted the car from a mass-market item into a fashionable icon because of the Retro design understanding. And since the day Mini came out with new Countryman and the new Mini S/SE. Even the 2023 Mini cooper SE has the characteristic tounches everywhere exterior and interior! KEEP READƒ∞NG DOWN BELOW. !!!

My objective thoughts and pros-cons list :
Pros:
1- Bigger battery; had to be improved because even cars like peugeot 208e-500e had bigger batteries than the previous generation Mini Cooper SE.

2- The chassis is lengthened; A longer chassis can provide more spacious interior and increases performance.

3- Growth of mirrors; I think it's counter-design, considering the iconic circular mirrors and iconic design language. However, for someone who is not very tall, larger and rectangular mirrors can be considered functional as they can minimize blind spots.

4- More options on Customization the Mini. Also great to see John Cooper Works exterior body kit so smooth...

5- More horse power means better perfomance! Great to see!

CONS; God! I'm furious and dissapointed the are too many of them! (OBJECTIVELY)
1- The black plastic artch trim has gone? Seriously? Those places especially if you live in cities will get tremendous amounts of small damages from other car doors and small physical contacts. Also where is the iconic design?

2- The taillights? What the hack you guys were thinking? The physical≈ü design had never changed since 1990's and you guys not only changed the shape, also ABOLISHED the Union jack Great Britan flag and instead put a triangular cheap material chinese looking lights.

3- ƒ∞nterior: The new generation automobile industry finds it right to express interior design in the most extreme way possible. But if we look at the cars that have reached the timeless design language. No matter what and what, you will not come across such a disgraceful interior design. The reason? The reason is that everywhere inside is made of a single material and they are trying to look as if it is a brand like Tesla. No my friend, this huge screen does not reflect the 1959 Central Speedo screen. There may be people who like it, but if everything is being completely electronic on a single screen, including the air conditioning controls, the car will be more anti-userfriendly and you will understand how useless it is after using it for a week. Also I don't think anyone has to like this stupidly designed "futuristic" steering wheel.

4- Interior buttons used to make you feel like you're in a spaceship or an airplane. This swisting and one-screen-everything buttons are definitely less charismatic than previous Mini's. More cheap material plastics being used and carpets everywhere making it like its only one piece carpet. Love to see and feels of the better quality materials on my Cooper SE! I love them.

I would be happier if I was able to see Mini brand not being gay and try to shine, wanting to be more popular, not following the stupid path started by other brands... if if if if.... Mini used to be Mini but not anymore it looks like. It doesn't feel like it. You also learn from your mistakes. No simplicity = No good.

comment:
Just got rid of our 2009 Mini Cooper - possibly one of the worst cars we‚Äôve owned. If you‚Äôre thinking of buying one I would strongly advise you not to. We had it 15 months and in that time the heater matrix failed, as did the drivers electric window regulator and the alternator.
We had several oil leaks fixed and we had a coolant leak from the radiator. All on a car that was 12 years old with only 85,000 miles and a fsh. The final straw was the last MOT advised that the valve stem seals needed to be replaced as the car was burning oil excessively causing it to almost fail its emissions test. The quote for that alone was over ¬£1000. These are BMW engines that you would imagine would be far more reliable. Save yourself the bother and buy a Japanese car.

comment: I have 2005 BMW 120d Sport Auto 55 plate with 153K miles bought in 2010 remapped to 200BHP/300lb-ft, uprated IC, lowered uprated (dual flow dampers for comfort and sportiness) suspension, Milltek exhaust, V Power diesel - like Boris I always try to build back better. Spent about ¬£13K in fixing it over 13 years that is without servicing, done most of the big jobs - turbo, 4 injectors, all the suspension front and rear arms, dampers, some of the bushes, radiator, condenser, alternator, idler, pulley, belts, steering rack. It drives like new, quite a lot of it is TBH. No DPF, EGR, SCR, swirl flaps or DFI, keep it till the auto gives up the ghost. Immacuately maintained, none of that lifetime fluids do the - rear diff oil, power steering, coolant every 100K, ATF & sump every 50K or 5 years, oil & filter every year or 12K miles etc. It's a good B road blaster...Keep it cause I know the service history - I buy the service fluids, oils and filters. I use a BMW specialist for repairs that insists on BMW franchise parts...I am an ownership kind of guy don't really like renting home or car. PCP once for a new Range Rover and had a 6 cylinder Boxster from Porsche franchise - wife said mid-life crisis. I'll tell you those Porsche dealership they treat you well, it's like you're part of the family. Pickup the car drop a curtesy car then once the servicing is done drop off the car. You have your own relationship manager, email or call them, they take care of everything sad to say but way better than Land Rover it's true luxury service not just in name. The drive belt was due but I didn't have time to get it done at Cambridge so they arranged it to be done Catania in Sicily with an English speaking rep. I mean that is what you call service. The service Porsche give they have won my heart, they just can't do enough for you. I used to test them to see if they would say no it was 10 year old Boxster any thing, they fixed it. I did track days in it, they changed suspension all under warranty. Amazing company and people...

comment:
The manufacturer may state the timing chain and the automatic transmission's lifetime (sealed) fluid may not need changing if maintenance intervals are respected. However, with the N14 /N18, I would humbly disagree. The timing chain, ESPECIALLY with the manufacturer recommended oil changes (every 10K miles), will most likely need a change at 50,000~70,000 Miles. In fact, the best way to extend the timing chain life is to increase the oil change frequency to every 5,000 miles. Unfortunately, on a used car...it's very difficult to verify the higher frequency of oil changes unless the maintenance history has been meticulously kept. I have an 11.2007 R55 S with the N14...and had the timing chain replaced (full kit) at 85,000 miles on the odometer...for around CHF2200...four years ago. I change the oil & filter myself every 5000 miles with 5W30 full synthetic. The car takes 4.2L...and I check the oil dipstick after every other fill-up of the gas tank. I keep a 1L bottle of oil in the car at all times...as it needs a 0.4L top off after every 750 miles. I try to keep levels on the high side of the dipstick measure. Bottom line...if you want that mini to last, CHECK and CHANGE the oil at 2x the manufacturer's recommended frequency. This is the one specific maintenance area where you need to be on-top of the situation with any N14/N18 Mini. Especially the N14.
As for the automatic (steptronic) transmission....DRAIN and REPLACE (do NOT flush) the fluid every 50,000 miles.
Lastly, I do use 6 oz's of SEAFOAM on the dirty side of the vacuum return hose from the N14 valve cover (upper left corner of the valve cover when facing the car) every 6 months. With a warm engine, I take a coffee-sized paper cup of SeaFoam, with my thumb over the removed vacuum hose, and slowly let the vacuum pull SeaFoam from the cup as I carefully tilt the cup (so as not to stall the engine...avoiding a vapor lock). I prefer to have someone in the car keeping the engine rev at 2000rpm while adding the SeaFoam. I then shutoff the car and let the SeaFoam sit in the air intake and above the valves for 0.5 hours. Thereafter, I run the car at 4K rpm for 5 minutes to clean out the excess carbon (until the smoke clears, so to speak). This is necessary due to the older Direct Fuel Injection system whereby carbon builds up around the valve tops. SeaFoam (or similar cleaners) does a good job of lessening the carbon build up. Not sure if this will avoid an expensive cleaning by a certified tech (with crushed walnut blasting)...but at least it extends the interval for said maintenance.
IMO, Mini's are a lot of fun to drive...sportive and good looking too! However, GEN2's are a terrible first car, unless that young driver has a family member (e.g., dad) that keeps track of the maintenance. Also, Mini S's and JCW's are probably not the best cars for young drivers...too much power in the hands of inexperienced drivers, IMO. Had a business colleague who's young brother-in-law was given a new Mini Cooper S upon graduation from university. Hit a signal pole and was killed, along with his 3 friends, while driving fast & furious.

People such as your buyers look at this car as a "cute car" that should be inexpensive to insure and easy to live with - looks can be deceiving. Having a "reserve fund" helps out too - I wish I had a dealer/mechanic willing to do a timing chain for that amount - I would have bought the car then and their.

comment:
Ehh. I've had experiences with actual skeevy car salesmen. Last car we bought from a dealership had an intermittent electrical problem that we're like 98.5% certain that the dealer knew about but didn't tell us about. The reason why we suspect they knew is because once the problem showed up and we started digging into it we noticed that the the wiring harness to the ECU was sliced open and the ECU connector was packed full of copper grease. I ended up having to diagnose and troubleshoot it myself because our mechanic thought it would be too expensive to have done professionally and recommended that we scrapped the car. Can't say i wouldn't have wanted to know about that problem beforehand, and we definitely wouldn't have paid what we did for the car if we'd known. Certainly would have beat being lied to and told that the car was in great condition and that it had been meticulously looked after by the previous owner.

So sure, if we're talking about completely car-illiterate people wanting to be told that a used car is basically never going to have to be repaired and never require any maintainence, then i can sort of see your argument. But if we're talking about dealers hiding and lying about faults in cars and then trying to gouge their customers for as much money as possible, then no. I can guarantee that absolutely nobody who's in the business of buying used cars wants that. And sadly i think that sort of behaviour is a lot more common than it should be, both when it comes to dealerships and private sales.

comment:
I bought my 05 Mini One Convertible in 2014. My local garage owner said to me; "People absolutely love them but I hope you have a credit card with plenty of credit on it."
In 7 years it's had a new power steering unit (BMW covered the cost), new clutch, new drive shaft, new radiator and reconditioned gearbox. The door seals leaked from when it was supplied to the first owner (the water channels inside the doors were poorly designed). It has cost me a fortune but it has been great fun to drive. I'm thinking about replacing it with a newer Mini. Unless the build quality has improved, I must need my head examining!
I wish more car dealers were as open and honest as you are. Unfortunately, we don't listen.

comment: A JCW Mini is a specialist car. You do right to put ignorant buyers off this car. The problem is finding a customer who understands what the car is and what they are getting. We got to the point where we asked for a nominal deposit to see the car if it was after normal opening hours, say ¬£25. It worked wonders at putting off tyre kickers. We only did this if we got a bad feeling about the prospective customer. Your point draws in the need to qualify the customer, then choose from your stock the cars best suited to their needs. Obviously when you hold hundreds of cars you can do this. Not so easy when you only have a handful for sale. My experience was that the level of customer ignorance cannot be underestimated. If you ever start taking part exchanges get ready for the avalanche of lies that ill come your way.

comment: The general public are foolish when they look to buy a car. They don't often care how much the purchase price is and they don't check if it's stolen or has genuine service history or mileage. They see it as a mode of transport and like the shiny ones best. Once purchased they don't want to spend a penny on maintenance and upkeep. I remember a chap I worked with traded in his 2 year old mini cooper s convertible because the brakes were making a noise. All it needed was a new set of pads. He never serviced it during his entire time of ownership either. He spent many times more buying a new car and trading in his old one than the maintenance costs. He then complained how unreliable his old car was. I budget repairs on my car every year. It's 10 years old so maintenance is to be expected and as a consequence it runs sweet as a nut :)

comment:
I used to be a hardcore MINI fan/owner. Ive owned 5 of them (3 first gen, 1 second gen, and one classic). The first gen new MINI (02-06) had it all right. The look, the driving dynamics, the engine sound, etc‚Ä¶..it was perfect. Then with each successive generation the car has become more and more bloated and less attractive to the point that I have pretty much zero interest in them now. BMW really had a great recipe 20 years ago when MINI came back‚Ä¶.you saw them everywhere. Nowadays, I hardly ever see a MINI, and if I do, it‚Äôs an older one. I‚Äôm sure it also has to do with consumer preference nowadays which leans towards huge SUVs and pickups. Just sad to me seeing this brand kind of lose its way over the years.

Great review as always, btw.

comment:
Had my BEV Countryman S E Sport L 3 since April 9 and the only faults I can find are the front seat head restraints force your head forward and that is uncomfortable and there are still a lot of bugs in the electronics in the dash - mine refuses point blank to give me satnav voice instructions in English, German, French, Spanish or Italian it just tells me that it doesn‚Äôt recognise those languages even though they (and a whole lot more languages are available) in the settings. Even when the setting is set to English I get a message on the screen telling me that English is not available for satnav instructions!
Not that it bothers me as 99% of my charging is at home but I also haven‚Äôt been able to get it to connect to the Plug and Charge system so,used my Electroverse card instead and got a discount on Octopus.
Drove mine to Harrogate and back last weekend and it‚Äôs a hoot to drive on the motorway and is very comfortable and quiet at speed. it‚Äôs not too thirsty at motorway speed having averaged 3.4m/kWh overall - charging on Ionity and EVPoint chargers was no problem at max 150kW but it‚Äôs a pity that the charging curve starts to taper off that at 35-37% SOC in this day and age. 40% to 80% on a 350kW Ionity at Carlisle took 20 minutes and 22 minutes on a 150kW charger at Starbucks in Harrogate to do similar. The augmented reality display is brilliant but spoken satnav routing instructions are more useful as you don‚Äôt have to take your eyes off the road to see where to turn. The ride is great on the 19‚Äù wheels on mine - I‚Äôm used to driving air sprung Range Rovers and New Defenders and it‚Äôs as comfortable as those even on rough road surfaces.
Might have been more appropriate of BMW Mini to have resurrected the old Maxi name for it though - it‚Äôs 10cms longer than my 2023 Defender 90, it cannot go quite as far off the tar as the Defender too even though mine has a ‚Äútrails‚Äù mode setting in the experiences - best to limit your off road ventures to a forest drive I have found.

comment:
I bought a new JCW CM all4 in 2018 from St Louis Mini. I loved the car. Then, in 2020, I bought a new 2020 JCW CM all4, which I still have. It only had 27K, so it is still in excellent condition. I wanted to test drive a new Clubman in 2022 while my car was being serviced. Everything was good until I couldn't find my car insurance so they wouldn't allow me to test it. I have been driving Minis since 1968 I bought my first one in Northern Italy. I intend to continue driving Minis until I can no longer handle a car safely. I hope that means another 75 years or so. I have the only JCW in Cape Girardeau; people love looking at it. It is White with Red Top and stripes on the hood and side!.
I‚Äôm as happy as a mouse in a cheese factory. Contented as a Carnation cow.
I‚Äôm ready to get the 2024 or 2025 now. I may try the JCW Clubman, though.
Live strong and prosper.

comment:
I have a three MINI family. The '05 R52 cabrio for zipping turns with the top down...pop, pop...growl.
The '21 Countryman SE All4 PHEV which is only topped by the JCW in the 0-60. As a daily drive it delivers 60 mpg winter- 80 mpg summer doing the 40 miles to work round trip. I just added a "19 Clubman S All4 8 speed automatic with paddle shifters...It is a solid comfortable MINI and delivers punch in Sport mode but averages over 30 mpg when tooling around town and back. comment: I just purchased the Countryman S for my wife and pre-ordered the Canyon AT4x for myself a few months back.  After driving her car I didn't want to give it back, so I decided to test drive the 2023 JCW Clubman, Countryman, and 2-door.  Ride and acceleration are almost identical in the Clubman and Countryman, the 2-door was tossed around like rag doll on the roads around DC.  Handling was quite a bit better on the Clubman.  I now have an order in for a custom JCW Clubman and have cancelled the pre-order for the AT4X (I'll buy an older truck for off-roading).  It was quite amazing how different all drive moved are, even in the standard sport to M sport mode.  The Countryman was still missing the pops and burbles, but the Clubman definitely had them with stock exhaust when shifted into M sport.

comment:
I borrowed a Countryman for a longer term test drive, and them a clubman, and chose the Clubman to have more of the MINI driving experience. Having the lower opening height for the boot was a plus for me too. I have a number of pups and one has had knee issues all her life and for to get in and out is much easier with the Clubman. When I spec out both cars, with the back seats down, the Clubman had just slightly more space than the Countryman, (2021 versions of both cars)

You mentioned the roof rails, My MINI didn‚Äôt come with them. There is a retro kit (multiple part numbers) for the Clubman roof rails from MINI. The issue is finding someone brave enough to do the installation. I found a auto collision shop here in Colorado, USA that installed them for me, and I love them!

I have driving my share of cars in my 62 years, and I have to say, I love driving my Clubman the most, and it is not even a JCW, but an S!!

comment:
Mini has got to be the most overpriced, irrelevant brand on the market. A Mini Countryman CW will realistically cost about $50,000. That money will easily get you into a BMW X3 or Mercedes GLC, which are larger, better engineered, more luxurious SUVs. Which still drive in a fairly sporty way. Even a Genesys GV80 is only $50,000. And, of course, Mazda, Toyota will sell you a huge, comfortable SUV for that price as well.

The Countryman is about the same money as a VW Golf Type R which is larger and more spacious, but handles just as well. And it's close to BMW 1 Series or Mercedes A Class pricing too.

Compared to these, the Mini is overpriced, undersized, under-engineered and not especially luxurious. They're unreliable and expensive to maintain too. Are they "British", though? Not so much anymore--it's all BMW parts through and through. Any resemblance to the British original is just a pastiche.

comment:
Interesting Pete, another comprehensive review. I have driven a countryman (only a Cooper) as a lone car, and I was quite impressed generally.
I was also offered a test drive in a JCW countryman when I ordered my Clubbie as they didn‚Äôt have one of those to test, but I declined.
I knew how special the new JCW Clubbie was going to be and I certainly wasn‚Äôt disappointed. The extra space in the Clubbie compared to my previous hatch is like a barn to me and very useful so I‚Äôm more than happy.
As previously mentioned somewhere, I have the adaptive dampers on mine and on normal setting they give a ready good ride. In sports mode they stiffen up to give a firmer ride but this is still very comfortable unless you hit a potholed road at town speeds.
I drive from 30 miles Brighton to Chichester and back every day to and from work. In the mornings it‚Äôs usually mid mode from the trip with the occasional blast in sport mode. Coming home 90`% of the time it‚Äôs in sports mode with dynamic traction switched onüòú, easily drivable in town and all the way home. Quite often my route changes to go through Amberley, Storrington , Steyning and down past the cement works to the flyover. I love my Clubbie ü§ó
The only thing that is frustrating my is the fitting of a rear dashcam. Easy on the hatchbacks but I cannot seem to find the best way of installing one on the Clubbie.
The barn doors swing away from the body as they open so it‚Äôs not easy to route the cables.
How about looking into this and doing a feature just for me-it would really help if I could find a solution (beg, beg, grovel..etc).
Love your vids mate, always a pleasure to watch.....(that‚Äôs another grovel).üòÇüëç
