comment:
1) Looks: All Mini are "cute" automobiles. No more , no less !
2) Rear room: You are the problem, not the cars ! You don't buy a Mini to haul people. Minis are made to haul groceries and other "small stuff".
3) Boot: Barn doors win all the time. I hate garage doors on any vehicle ! But, the best has to be tail gates (like on pick-ups) !
4) You don't buy a Mini to haul a bicycle because bicycles are bigger ! With an adequate rear rack on the bicycle your could haul the Mini on the back of the bicycle !
5) If you require the additional purchase of a roof box (Give away !) The car is too small !
6) Driving position: The number one shock ! You're sitting on the wrong side of the car ! ! You would be in heaven if you get a Ferrari F2004 ! It's seating position is pretty low.
7) Ride quality: Really ? We are talking about a Mini are we not ? A lorry has a better ride quality for goodness sake ! Now back to my Flex, that is ride quality. I mean it, try it and you'll be blown away ! (By the way, did I mention that you are seating on the wrong side of the car !) MY GOOD LORD ! YOU'RE EVEN ON THE WRONG SIDE OF THE ROAD ! ! ! I too had 255/45R20 on my Ford and they are beautiful to look at as with the Minis but I changed for 235/60R18 to get some road comfort ! A wheel rim with a smidge of rubber does not equate comfort !
8) Engine/Exhaust noise: Any one of these are a problem.....return the car promptly to your dealer ! We are in 2021, cars are not supposed to make noise ! I tell you, get a Ferrari F2004, it screams !
9) 0-60-0: How does this work out in downtown London ? I thought so ! Just to make things even, my Ford Flex (290 hp) 4700 lbs curb weight 0-60 in 7.7 sec ! (Had I the Turbo oooohhh ! ) It could scream 0-60 in 5.9 sec ! And we are hauling 4,800 lbs curb weight !
10) I get the feeling you like go-carts.......oh, you do ! (I'm watching the video and pause as I write) !
11) As a second errand getter I'd love a Mini....they are cute and fun little car.
12) Great content, love the videos ! Thanks
Foot note:
I own a Ford Flex AWD Limited (sadly the last year of manufacture 2019).....now for the fun, redo this entire review with a Flex ! You'll understand everything ! Now bring the Minis and do the same review in Canada, in January ! We'll have real fun !

comment: Nice comparison, PP! The better head and legroom sold me on my '20 Countryman JCW over the Clubman. I have a very long torso, so most cars don't fit me. It is the only car with a sunroof/moonroof I have ever been able to fit in comfortably. I also managed to fit a large-sized Specialized Roll sportbike in the rear by turning the front wheel/handlebars 90 degrees. It's a tight fit, but it works. I agree about the analog driver binnacle vs. the digital. I'm seriously thinking about the Remus exhaust though after I upgrade to the Michelin PS4s. On my local MINI club runs on b-roads, I have yet to be left in any other MINI's dust. ;-) I cannot help but grin ear-to-ear every time I sit behind the wheel of my Countryman, and it is definitely my favorite car I've ever owned. It drives like a much smaller car, but with a comfortable ride and great utility in the back seat and boot.

comment:
In the last few years, the car industry has decimated the compact car class to a devastating degree. If you're a buyer like I am, and you want a compact car, your choices are now horribly limited. The Mini now being not just one of the best, but one of the only choices left. Perfect example of what I mean:

VW's current generation "Compact" Jetta. Look at it. In terms of size, it's a VW Mid-size Passat masquerading as a Jetta. If I wanted more room in the boot or a backseat that could comfortably carry adults for hours at a time, I'd buy another Mid-size sedan. Bought one years ago, personally; it was a mistake. I don't care if the backseat is not suitable for two large adults. It'll rarely see anyone's backside. The boot is plenty big enough for a breakdown bag, and my work-bag; without the rear seats folded flat. Some folks genuinely desire a compact car that doesn't take up unnecessary space in their lives, is easy to park, and has a bit of performance under the hood.

comment: Awful car, one of the worst cars I have ever driven, aside from the Fiat 500X which is just terrible. I have been driving one for two weeks, I do a 100 mile round trip to work each day. Its like driving a fish tank with a fisher-price steering wheel. Ok the 2 litre is pokey and it handles well, but the driving position is uncomfortable, the steering wheel can only be adjusted up and down. The door speaker is right where your knee rests, the centre console has an edge that digs into the other leg. What is that handbrake thing? The dash is just shite, hard to read the speedo and rev counter, the fuel computer is in litres/ 100km so is useless unless you have a calculator on hand. You can't read what the switch gear does and its just too far away for practicality. That big round thing with the screen is just ugly and the connectivity is awful and for android: only bluetooth connectivity (Before July 2020). Boot is tiny. Oh, and sounds terrible, like somebody farting into a biscuit tin. The fake carbon fibre dash doesn't look like carbon fibre (why not use carbon fibre?) is cheap and tacky. The car is all quirk and no substance. I'm sure there's more. Just awful. Avoid like the plague.

comment:
This is probably the most disappointing review I have ever seen on FC. The sheer bias was astounding. I have been in both new and old MINI electrics.

The original is faster ( quote the official figures and lose all credibility), lighter by over 240Kg, more efficient, better handling, better looking, better made yet this car seems to have the sun shine out its missing tailpipe.

The original will get better than WLTP every day of the week. That is 144 miles r.ange. Personally, range is the most overrated feature of any electric car.

Did you know that MINI apparently had to ease up on the traction control because it was so good people thought the car was slow or under powered? In reality it is faster than the new model.

The aesthetics are terrible In my eye, but I am biased so let's ignore that. Did you know the outgoing model has the same HUD? It isn't a new thing.

So many, in my mind, hideously biased comments about the old car, which is in every metric other than range, better. It was cheaper as well. In Oz it was the same price as the petrol with the same spec.

I have been watching FC for many years and this is the first time I have been angry about a review. The new MINI isn't an improvement, and in most cases worse. Please be honest otherwise it sounds like you have been paid to say things.

For those wondering, I have had an SE for almost 4 years and have also tried the new SE so I know what I am saying. Now I wish MINI well, and this car will no doubt attract a new audience, but it is in no way an improvement.

I apologise for being so direct, but this really got me angry. I thought more of FC.

comment:
Audi dropping E-Tron. Mercedes axing EQ series. Fisker bankrupt. Charge Cars collapsed into administration on May 31 without a single one of its cars reaching customers. The automotive industry issued renewed pleas for electric car purchase incentives after new figures showed a decline in the vehicles' market share. Some 15.2% of new cars registered in March were pure electrics, down from 16.2% during the same month last year, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT). The survey of over 300,000 vehicles found electric models suffer 79% more maintenance problems than gas-powered cars. Meanwhile, plug-in hybrids fared even worse with a concerning 146% more issues reported by drivers.

Volvo XC40 catches fire and a child was rescued in a recent fire involving a brand new Volvo XC40 hybrid and raises concerns about electric car safety. The driver, who just received the car, managed to rescue his granddaughter before it exploded In a daring rescue, a motorist sustained severe burns pulling his 19-month-old granddaughter from the back seat as his brand-new hybrid car went up in flames and exploded. Seeing smoke, David Butler, a retired engineer at 67, sprang into action. His wife Anne, also 67, had turned back to witness the horror. The rear seat, where their toddler sat in a baby seat, was engulfed in flames, intense "as if someone had poured petrol on a barbecue." With a screeching halt, Butler scrambled to reach his granddaughter, Lilly. Much to his chagrin, the rear door of their Volvo XC40, which could run on both gasoline and electric power, refused to budge.Undeterred by the smoke and flames, he clambered back into the front seat and, with a determined reach, managed to unbuckle and free his granddaughter. "Fortunately, I managed to feel for the seat release and dragged her out of the car," he said in a¬†Facebook post. "As I did this, the hybrid battery exploded, igniting the fuel tank and filling the car with flames. I managed to get out but was on fire," he added. Road maintenance workers joined Butler in pulling his granddaughter to safety. He was rushed to the hospital with severe burns covering 60 percent of his body. Lilly, too, required medical attention.

Your EV utopian future.

comment: Mr Llewellyn - please do not dismiss the driving for 3hrs at national speed limit on the motorway and make small the challenges that this car has. A combustion engined mini can do long distance, the battery cannot. The petrochemical fuel cel dimensions and efficiency, based on the chassis size and battery that can be fitted, will always be an issue. If you can only afford ONE car, the MG4, is a good example. When theses EV's trickle down to the used marketplace, people have one choice as their only car. 70 miles an hour for 3 hours on a UK motorway, at 3.5kW/mile = 60kW battery. This is a benchmark for many people who do the longer trips on a holiday to the lakes, cotswolds, Cornwall, Scotland, Norfolk  (vis-a-vis). Depreciation will get people into better cars for sure - my 71 plate Zoe cost ¬£36k. I have one year of my PCP remaining and autotrader prices are ¬£10k - so trade-in will be lower, meaning we will just walk away and leave the car, requiring us to look again at other transport solutions - I'm thinking an older classic that is ULEZ free seen as EV's will now have to pay the congestion charge anyway....

comment:
Can't speak for the Euro market, but here in the States there's a well known issue with pricing. EVs initially had some tax incentives for being "green" (varies by state). But they were higher priced as a new technology, high cost of manufacturing, expensive batteries etc. Then state governments realized they were loosing a decent bit of bag from taxes at the fuel pump.

Fast forward a few years, and now manufacturing is a bit more dialed in, battery tech has become more efficient and pricing for batteries has gone down. But the governments imposed sly tax slaps on EV's to recover the revenue lost from fuel purchases. Ironically, the standard half ton pick-up (i.e. Ford F150, Chevy Silverado 1500 etc.) have become one of the most popular vehicles here, and price to power/price to weight of material sold is quite low (relative to modern pricing. Some of these top model trucks/SUVs go beyond $100k which is ludicrous)

Depending on the state, there is a bit of a tax incentive on makers/dealers to sell vehicles below 25 mph because it increases fuel sales. Add-on that in many agricultural states (I live in Florida, for example) these standard pick-ups are categorized as a tool to assist in agricultural economy and are then incentivized even more. They are also socially/ideologically considered safer, so insurance is often less, and these models are popular so parts are readily available. etc. etc. etc.

Never owned an EV. The areas I live in are not perfectly fit for it in my use case. So I am not sure what taxes are put on electricity purchases at charging stations. I would imagine it's still a commodity when used as vehicle power. But maybe it's considered a utility purchase? I don't see why they wouldn't be able to tax charging stations like fuel pumps to at least make the vehicle value more appealing.

comment:
I owned a MINI SE (2021) for three years and it was a lot better than Robert's assessment of the outgoing model. Few modern ground-up EVs are as efficient - I got 4.3mi/kWh over the winter.
BUT.. the cost of the MINI has jumped from the low ¬£20k's at launch to the mid ¬£30k's and to replace my 2021 model with the new MINI would cost ¬£35k for an equivalent model.
I used to own a 2016 MINI Cooper and wanted a similar five door electric (back in 2021). I was hoping this time, MINI would correct their error of omitting a five door option from the electric range (while still offering it in petrol?), but they didn't. The Aceman is a Countryman light, not a Cooper - and frankly looks awful. So I bought a Volvo EX30, which has five doors, is faster (nice but not critical) has Over the Air Updates (don't want to spend a day at the garage for a 20 min firmware update like I did with the old MINI), is only slightly bigger than the MINI, has a similar ride (but much better suspension) and costs less.
IMO as a MINI fan and EV owner, MINI need to add a five door Cooper and drop the price or up the range (one or the other) as the current options are poor value, when compared to Smart #1/#3, Volvo EX30, MG4, the soon to arrive Renault 5 and now the prices have dropped, Corsa E and Fiat 500e.
The same was true of the Honda E. Great car at ¬£8k-¬£10k less, but just too expensive for what was offered.
The new MINI is a Chinese car at Oxford prices.

comment: Great review Rob! I had the F56 Mini Electric, I loved it. You got to consider the Mini factor, about 100miles is about 90miles once you've really booted it! I loved my 'old' Mini Electric but with a fatal flaw of 90miles range, it really wasn't usable even for motorway commuting as you can't guarantee the destination would have charging and public charging is so costly anyway. I suspect with the newest mini ev, the range of approx 150miles would drop to around 130miles once you had abit of fun in it! Still not a usable range in my opinion, I think 200miles is an optimum range in the UK to get from A-B and back again without getting stung by public charging, which in some cases is more expensive than fuel... I think it should really be used to top up. I found myself regularly charging near empty at public chargers. I've gone back to petrol. But in the hope that public leccy will get less expensive and when EV's come down in price with an effective range of around 200miles :)

comment:
I was expecting good things from the Aceman but I'm not too sure looking at it now. I've had lots of the R series MINIs but never fell in love with the F series. For me, I hate the plastic cladding, which always fades, and welcomed the cleaner look of the new electric J series. What a pity MINI decided to keep so much plastic on the Aceman so it's more 'rugged' looking - not that it will ever go offroad. With all that being said, the interior looks great.

Whilst the driving experience was awful, I still prefer the look of the Paceman.

comment:
I stumbled across your channel yesterday and since I'm on my third Mini, was interested in watching your reviews. First, I absolutely love your channel! You guys do such a fabulous job with both the pros and cons of owning a MIni Cooper. That said, I disagreed with the one negative comment that was made regarding how there hasn't been many changes over the years to the overall style. For me, there has been too many changes in order to modernize the brand. They need to stick with the retro look. I remember the days when all the cars looked different from each other and nowadays, with very few exceptions, they all look relatively the same. No artistic characteristics that makes the car unique. The dashboard of the Mini should keep as close to the original style as possible. Trying to keep up with the Jones mentality is what's ruining the auto industry. The Mini roadster was so cool! I understand sales weren't going well, but to discontinue it was a mistake. The trend at that time was to make larger vehicles to please the damn soccer moms. Okay, I'm off my soap box now.
Thanks again for your informative videos.

comment:
I'm a late-comer to the Mini scene, although I have grown up with BMC-era Austins (primarily A30 and A35). I did once own a 1974 Morris 1300GT and totally regret selling it because it was not only comfortable to ride in, but it was also very quick and the owner after me wrapped it around a telephone pole....but I digress.

I helped a mate pull a dilapidated hulk of a '64 Mk1 850 Morris Mini-Minor out of a field on a farm when we were both 15. He'd been given it by his brother (who was share-milking the herd at the time) on the proviso that we could get it out from under the trees where it sat for 3 years, get it running and drive it up to the farmhouse about a mile away. It was half buried in Macrocarpa needles, but we dug it out, pushed it into a handy barn because it was raining and set to work. The electric fuel pump didn't work, so I hooked up a drip feed to the carburettor using the original Tudor washer bottle (I'd seen my Dad do that to an A30 we had on the lawn a few month's prior) while my mate cleaned the plugs, points and dizzy cap poles. Ironically, I had to siphon fuel from the Mini's tank to fill the washer bottle! One other minor issue was the lack of floor in the boot to put the battery on, so I pushed the mains cable through a rust hole into the back seat area, ripped the earth strap off the boot remains and clamped that to the metal lip of the RH companion box. The battery was then jammed between the seat back and a lump of timber that sat against the front lip of the lower seat shelf and connected up. She fired up more or less straight away after that. The car had brakes (surprisingly) but the clutch didn't disengage so you could get it into gear until you pumped the pedal about 20 times.....but we figured it out, got it moving and drove it up to the farmhouse in triumph. The next couple of days were devoted to fixing what we could (the fuel pump was an easy first target) with no money, no spare parts, a limited tool set and my knowledge gained from working with my father on his (and his mates') mechanical projects over the years. We had a ball - and the car became a very smart beasty that gave him a lot of very reliable miles over the next few years.

Fast forward to about six years ago and my youngest daughter is following me around classic car shows....and she sees a Mini up close for the first time and falls in love with it. Fast forward to last year and my eldest decides she loves the car I bought for the two of them to learn to drive in and wants to keep it as hers. My plan was for them to buy their own and the 'learner' car be on-sold.....but plans sometimes have to change. Youngest then announces that she will need a car to learn in....and that it should be a Mini. So...sitting downstairs is a 1977 Mk4 Austin Mini 1000 powered by a 1275cc engine. I was determined that some things were going to happen to it to improve its safety a touch - ones I could get away with without having to get them certified, which is a long and tiresome process in this country, with much red tape and usually with an inspector who interprets rules as he sees fit, rather than bearing any resemblance to fact.....but I digress again. It now sports 7.5" Cooper disc brakes with EBC Greenstuff pads, widened drums in the rear, 12" Cosmic Mk4 alloy wheels with new tyres, Hella headlights, Hella Comet 500 driving lights, new cones, shocks, stabiliser bushes, engine / subframe mounts and any rubberised or jointed thing up front that had the slightest amount of play has been upgraded or replaced. The wiring has been checked over and modernised to include more relays and wedge fuses than standard rather than relying on four larger amp glass tube ones to run the lot. The interior has had new pedal rubbers, a volt meter and rev counter mounted tastefully to complete the full gauge set, a pile of soundproofing added under its new carpet (and firewall, doors etc) and all seals and runners on doors, door openings and windows (including the bootlid) are new. It looks very smart in Signal red with its Old English white roof and bonnet stripes....as long as you do not get too close and see the touch-ups I have done or the work that still needs doing. I consider bodywork to be the last thing on the agenda as she is likely to get some battle scars during the learning process and these will all be attended to later and have just devoted myself to keeping the rust at bay. I love driving this little car as it drives like nothing else I have ever driven. It surely has to be one of the most enjoyable vehicles in that you can drive it so quickly and aggressively and still remain under the speed limit with a huge grin etched on your face! When Youngest eventually takes it and moves out, it will be a very sad day for me, so I think I will have to buy another one. Do I have a favourite Mini though? Yes - I'd love a 1981 or later 1275GT in metallic Chocolate Bronze....or whatever they called the colour (very similar to the Ford colour Roman Bronze). I love the Clubman shape, but Youngest loves the round nose more....and it just happened that the one we have now was the one that was in the right place at the right time....else it would have been a Clubby GT.....or maybe a Clubman Estate / Countryman.

Many thanks for the effort in turning all those pix into a film - it was lovely to see them all.

channel_title: 1A Auto: Repair Tips & Secrets Only Mechanics Know
comment: I got a 2007 Mini Cooper I first rented ,  then i bought it as the price was $5K above the Blue book. Now I have 75K miles and basically have had no problem. Brake pads are not cheap, but I have had leaks here and there over the last few years. I got greasy spots in my garage, so what ? Now I just got the sign of engine "stress", not overheating, just that stress sign. I took it to the dealer and got an oil change. Double checked it, when I  got home, to make sure they really did ! Ha...They also gave me  an estimate of what suggested repairs should be as I refused their electronic eval. I just wanted an oil change ! not any diagnosis. Well, they found multiple leaks and even suggested I replaced all tires, which are all having deep threads and grooves,  so NO, not ready to replace. The total was over $8.7K ! Unf.... believable as it is more than the current value of the car. What disgusting scam ! Did they think I am an idiot ? I will drive that car with the engine light on, as a fixture. I will check my oil often and drive less aggressively. I only drive between the grocery store and my house. I am retired !  and considering riding my bicycle.......Screw the cars......and the car dealers, well, metaphorically........Not getting my business, ever again. What scam ! They never mentioned any potential damage to the catalytic converter.....why not ???these suckers are expensive and never in all these years I had the car,  one of these frauds, mentioned I should replace the spark plugs.....Hmmmm. They prefer to take down engines and replace the seals......they can make more money that way.......

comment: I always wanted the "new" MINI to be a success but BMW fought me all the way. It's always been about perception and profit. Any "new" MINI would be a great car to rent but not to buy or lease. The "classic" aka "real" Austin Mini (Cooper) never pretended to be anything it wasn't. As a previous owner of one, I can tell you that anyone who bought a "Little British Car" aka LBC loved small fun cars and he/she knew that working on them was part of the fun of ownership. It eventually became part of you. The "new" BMW/MINI has always been about prestige and image. It never appealed to me and still doesn't.

comment:
I bought a new JCW CM all4 in 2018 from St Louis Mini. I loved the car. Then, in 2020, I bought a new 2020 JCW CM all4, which I still have. It only had 27K, so it is still in excellent condition. I wanted to test drive a new Clubman in 2022 while my car was being serviced. Everything was good until I couldn't find my car insurance so they wouldn't allow me to test it. I have been driving Minis since 1968 I bought my first one in Northern Italy. I intend to continue driving Minis until I can no longer handle a car safely. I hope that means another 75 years or so. I have the only JCW in Cape Girardeau; people love looking at it. It is White with Red Top and stripes on the hood and side!.
I‚Äôm as happy as a mouse in a cheese factory. Contented as a Carnation cow.
I‚Äôm ready to get the 2024 or 2025 now. I may try the JCW Clubman, though.
Live strong and prosper.

comment:
I have a three MINI family. The '05 R52 cabrio for zipping turns with the top down...pop, pop...growl.
The '21 Countryman SE All4 PHEV which is only topped by the JCW in the 0-60. As a daily drive it delivers 60 mpg winter- 80 mpg summer doing the 40 miles to work round trip. I just added a "19 Clubman S All4 8 speed automatic with paddle shifters...It is a solid comfortable MINI and delivers punch in Sport mode but averages over 30 mpg when tooling around town and back. The driving fun factor list is R52 Cooper S 1st, next Clubbie, last Countryman...the last two being so much alike inside that they are operationally interchangeable.

comment: I just purchased the Countryman S for my wife and pre-ordered the Canyon AT4x for myself a few months back.  After driving her car I didn't want to give it back, so I decided to test drive the 2023 JCW Clubman, Countryman, and 2-door.  Ride and acceleration are almost identical in the Clubman and Countryman, the 2-door was tossed around like rag doll on the roads around DC.  Handling was quite a bit better on the Clubman.  I now have an order in for a custom JCW Clubman and have cancelled the pre-order for the AT4X (I'll buy an older truck for off-roading).  It was quite amazing how different all drive moved are, even in the standard sport to M sport mode.  The Countryman was still missing the pops and burbles, but the Clubman definitely had them with stock exhaust when shifted into M sport.

comment:
I borrowed a Countryman for a longer term test drive, and them a clubman, and chose the Clubman to have more of the MINI driving experience. Having the lower opening height for the boot was a plus for me too. I have a number of pups and one has had knee issues all her life and for to get in and out is much easier with the Clubman. When I spec out both cars, with the back seats down, the Clubman had just slightly more space than the Countryman, (2021 versions of both cars)

You mentioned the roof rails, My MINI didn‚Äôt come with them. There is a retro kit (multiple part numbers) for the Clubman roof rails from MINI. The issue is finding someone brave enough to do the installation. I found a auto collision shop here in Colorado, USA that installed them for me, and I love them!

I have driving my share of cars in my 62 years, and I have to say, I love driving my Clubman the most, and it is not even a JCW, but an S!!

comment:
Mini has got to be the most overpriced, irrelevant brand on the market. A Mini Countryman CW will realistically cost about $50,000. That money will easily get you into a BMW X3 or Mercedes GLC, which are larger, better engineered, more luxurious SUVs. Which still drive in a fairly sporty way. Even a Genesys GV80 is only $50,000. And, of course, Mazda, Toyota will sell you a huge, comfortable SUV for that price as well.

The Countryman is about the same money as a VW Golf Type R which is larger and more spacious, but handles just as well. And it's close to BMW 1 Series or Mercedes A Class pricing too.

Compared to these, the Mini is overpriced, undersized, under-engineered and not especially luxurious. They're unreliable and expensive to maintain too. Are they "British", though? Not so much anymore--it's all BMW parts through and through. Any resemblance to the British original is just a pastiche.

comment:
Interesting Pete, another comprehensive review. I have driven a countryman (only a Cooper) as a lone car, and I was quite impressed generally.
I was also offered a test drive in a JCW countryman when I ordered my Clubbie as they didn‚Äôt have one of those to test, but I declined.
I knew how special the new JCW Clubbie was going to be and I certainly wasn‚Äôt disappointed. The extra space in the Clubbie compared to my previous hatch is like a barn to me and very useful so I‚Äôm more than happy.
As previously mentioned somewhere, I have the adaptive dampers on mine and on normal setting they give a ready good ride. In sports mode they stiffen up to give a firmer ride but this is still very comfortable unless you hit a potholed road at town speeds.
I drive from 30 miles Brighton to Chichester and back every day to and from work. In the mornings it‚Äôs usually mid mode from the trip with the occasional blast in sport mode. Coming home 90`% of the time it‚Äôs in sports mode with dynamic traction switched onüòú, easily drivable in town and all the way home. Quite often my route changes to go through Amberley, Storrington , Steyning and down past the cement works to the flyover. I love my Clubbie ü§ó
The only thing that is frustrating my is the fitting of a rear dashcam. Easy on the hatchbacks but I cannot seem to find the best way of installing one on the Clubbie.
The barn doors swing away from the body as they open so it‚Äôs not easy to route the cables.
How about looking into this and doing a feature just for me-it would really help if I could find a solution (beg, beg, grovel..etc).

comment:
1) Looks: All Mini are "cute" automobiles. No more , no less !
2) Rear room: You are the problem, not the cars ! You don't buy a Mini to haul people. Minis are made to haul groceries and other "small stuff".
3) Boot: Barn doors win all the time. I hate garage doors on any vehicle ! But, the best has to be tail gates (like on pick-ups) !
4) You don't buy a Mini to haul a bicycle because bicycles are bigger ! With an adequate rear rack on the bicycle your could haul the Mini on the back of the bicycle !
5) If you require the additional purchase of a roof box (Give away !) The car is too small !
6) Driving position: The number one shock ! You're sitting on the wrong side of the car ! ! You would be in heaven if you get a Ferrari F2004 ! It's seating position is pretty low.
7) Ride quality: Really ? We are talking about a Mini are we not ? A lorry has a better ride quality for goodness sake ! Now back to my Flex, that is ride quality. I mean it, try it and you'll be blown away ! (By the way, did I mention that you are seating on the wrong side of the car !) MY GOOD LORD ! YOU'RE EVEN ON THE WRONG SIDE OF THE ROAD ! ! ! I too had 255/45R20 on my Ford and they are beautiful to look at as with the Minis but I changed for 235/60R18 to get some road comfort ! A wheel rim with a smidge of rubber does not equate comfort !
8) Engine/Exhaust noise: Any one of these are a problem.....return the car promptly to your dealer ! We are in 2021, cars are not supposed to make noise ! I tell you, get a Ferrari F2004, it screams !
9) 0-60-0: How does this work out in downtown London ? I thought so ! Just to make things even, my Ford Flex (290 hp) 4700 lbs curb weight 0-60 in 7.7 sec ! (Had I the Turbo oooohhh ! ) It could scream 0-60 in 5.9 sec ! And we are hauling 4,800 lbs curb weight !
10) I get the feeling you like go-carts.......oh, you do ! (I'm watching the video and pause as I write) !
11) As a second errand getter I'd love a Mini....they are cute and fun little car.
12) Great content, love the videos ! Thanks
Foot note:
I own a Ford Flex AWD Limited (sadly the last year of manufacture 2019).....now for the fun, redo this entire review with a Flex ! You'll understand everything ! Now bring the Minis and do the same review in Canada, in January ! We'll have real fun !

comment: Nice comparison, PP! The better head and legroom sold me on my '20 Countryman JCW over the Clubman. I have a very long torso, so most cars don't fit me. It is the only car with a sunroof/moonroof I have ever been able to fit in comfortably. I also managed to fit a large-sized Specialized Roll sportbike in the rear by turning the front wheel/handlebars 90 degrees. It's a tight fit, but it works. I agree about the analog driver binnacle vs. the digital. I'm seriously thinking about the Remus exhaust though after I upgrade to the Michelin PS4s. On my local MINI club runs on b-roads, I have yet to be left in any other MINI's dust. ;-) I cannot help but grin ear-to-ear every time I sit behind the wheel of my Countryman, and it is definitely my favorite car I've ever owned. It drives like a much smaller car, but with a comfortable ride and great utility in the back seat and boot.

comment: Interesting review. However, having seen other reviews reach 100-130 miles, I feel that where you drive it makes a difference too. Historically, with maximum regeneration on the brakes, electric cars do better in towns and cities. This is due to the need to start and stop and brake more regularly, (thus generating more electric current from the brakes). I would love to see how many laps of a real track these cars can do. With the constant need for acceleration and intense braking, it should really put an electric car to the test.

comment:
Nice review üëçBeeing here in Europe, having configured&bought an orange LCI 1 (facelift version 1) JCW new in 2018 (which sounds meaner & goes quicker than this new version - due to no particulate filter and claimed 231hp, showing actual 245hp on the dyno w/o any tuneup), blacked out around including beltline with all OG parts (think of KTM X-Bow colour scheme) for 4 years now:
Yes, it's a love or loathe thing. And if you want it, you have to have the money.
And for maintenance/parts/mechanics - it sure helps to be on the same continent as the manufacturer - many forget that, so a EU/US/Asian car can be perfect (or a nightmare) simply depending by where you are.
And sure, if you are after pure "going from A to B", cost/bang for buck ratio, or after pure numbers or sole performance (for weekend on racetracks) - plenty of better options out there.
So the ultimate reason for me getting - and keeping it for good - is:
uber nice ambiente and quality (for a car that size!), an iconic shape, absolutely unique design and details, customizability, all focused on fun and driving, yet refined and grown up enough to make long 2-3 person trips, or 240km/h+ blasts on the Autobahn, or plowing through winding alpine roads in a seemingly perfect rounded package.
With the BMW B48 engine in the A20O1 variant also a marvellous, really reliable and very good choice (in fact so good it was since 2014, and still is, the current BMW 4cyl. gasoline engine used in every new BMW, and also the new 2025 Gen.4 Mini, with only very few&minor optimisations needed in all those years - which is an indication for a brand, that essentially was, and is, an engine maker hence it's name since 1916).
With only 1200kg to pull - in a time, where almost every car is 1500 or 2000kg+ (and thus not fun or sporty by physics alone - thus requiring more of all, power, diffs, rims/tires etc. to compensate) - the reason it drives so well&refined.
So in 1 sentence: it's like a sportsbike that touches you emotionally, and it's the car you already start smiling even when thinking of getting into it to drive.
Like drive a Honda, Yamaha, Suzuki - or drive a KTM, Ducati, Harley - if you try, you know there is a difference.
There are tons of other cars that are objectively better in this or that metric - but seriously - most of them are "mainstream designed to please everybody and his grandma" = which is certainly not attracting me, boring, dull, uninspiring, all too serious or too comfortable - but in essence certainly not something you REALLY look forward to driving.
That's why JCW (and the Cooper S) is a niche of its own - and a nice, premium yet uniquely/funky/silly designed, daily-able fun car,
between the pure but painfully archaic lightweight performance cars (i'm talking BAC Mono, KTM XBox, Caterham Super7, Ariel Atom),
the IMO bluntly-lame-as-can-be-designed, can-do-be-all-but-be-nothing-special-by-itself-allrounders, not more than overly fat and weighty sporty versions of mum's shopping car (Golf, Hyundai and all the others) - or really serious/focused cars (like the GR Yaris) which sacrify style/quality/niceness/"daily comfort" for cheap plastic and pure function, and the expensive/luxurious side of performance cars (the high powered 3 german brands, and Porsche, Ferrari, Aston Martin, McLaren etc.) - you can't even dare to have fun on public roads, either by speed limits/laws, or the risk of a tiny mishap - as a custom front splitter, carbon bumper or 1 body panel alone costs more than a fully specced JCW... üòâ
ps. In my other 2 cars - i also have 3 doors and frameless windows. 4/5 door/SUV? Yikes....
ps2. The 18" alloys are too much and beyond the border of diminishing returns. 17" rims/tires are the way to go if you want the best out of a Cooper S/JCW.
ps3. Even if you put 1500hp in a i30N - it's still a dull soccer mom car. It's not all about function/numbers/metrics/perfectiosn - it's about "the perfect blend", and that's why icons are icons, and last in memory forever (the OG Audi S1 Quattro, the perfectly designed Porsche 911, the OG VW Beetle, the Lancia Stratos, the old SL Merc's, the C1 and C2 Corvettes etc. - and the Mini....) - whilest the 9th iteration, for the 13th time radically "optimized" version of mass product X is sooner forgotten than you can spell it's brands name.
If you need to google up to know, how the 3rd version of car X looked like: then it's one of those.
ps4. Mazda Miata. That's a different body style, but good contender/comparison for the JCW.
ps5. 2024, 6 years - still running like on day 1, and still loving it like on day 1. It will not be sold. Probably never.

comment:
Some of the F56 mini cooper s models didn't come with paddle shifters. I'm not sure if I'm the only one that experienced this, but if feels like using the manual shifter wore out the trans. When I traded up for my JCW That came with paddle shifters, I basically lift and shifted my mods and with the same amount of usage the transmission still feels brand new as apposed to my S model that felt like the trans wasn't grabbing as quickly when putting it in Sport manual, and felt like the trans wouldn't hold down the power in the corners evener with DSC turned off.

I'm almost positive they are the same trans it's just a added option to the steering wheel, but I mean it when I say it's a night and day difference. Not sure if anyone else experienced something similar.

comment: I bought a 2016 JCW so my completely biased rank is JCW, Type R, STI, RS. The compact nimble Mini just works so brilliantly in crowded cities (daily driving) and twisty hill roads (weekend fun). The cabin and boot spaces are not huge but still good enough for common occasions. Its under steer is not happening on streets but is quite noticeable on a track, so not good enough as a track day toy (too pricey as well). Overall, it is a great little fun car for urban use and I love it so much. Type R is great car, high tech and good value. But I think the new civic is massive, the Type R aero pack looks too aggressive/yobbish, and Honda cheated on the lap time on Nurburgring affected my first impression. STI is a all time great car but 2017/18 model is a bit outdated. I hope Subaru can get new WRX engine and face-lift styles installed on its 19 model. RS looks and sounds great, but the engine head gasket failure (in only 2 years, seriously?) is a big no to me.

1) Minor wear and tear on a 20 year car surely should be expected. The Mini interior quality far exceeded the norms of its day. High tech didn't really exist for in car deicers aids back then either.
2) you're waling away because a car gas kerb rash? Really? Wheel refurb is a really cheap and quick fix.
3)Terrifying like its falling apart? Hahahaha
4) Showing its age? Which other 23 year old cars are even still on the road in such high numbers?
5) These cars are not appealing to the same owners as MX5's which are more common than flies, have crap interiors and the roofs rear window rot completely out in the sun...

The Mini is a stylish drivers car. The power to weight ratio, the pointy steering and the excellent handling are the reason why people buy these cars. Anyone else who gets a 20+ year old car is probably looking for basic transport based on price and will buy the shiniest car their 2K will buy -it will be a beater beset by problems regardless.

They do consume oil, so regular oil checks should be done. High Pressure Fuel pumps fail at around 100K miles. Your point about the subframe was really valid.

So should you tell not to buy one? You should perhaps tell people not to buy any old cheap car unless you have money or time to invest. But if that sounds like you, a better looking all round driving car will be hard to find at that price point.

I'm posting this 'cause you asked for comments.

comment:
short answer: mini coopers are mostly high maintenance, and rock solid if properly maintained, but they don't often appeal to people who are rigid about maintenance so used ones tend to need a lot of work to be reliable.

If you do the maintenance, they are great cars. Repairs and parts may be expensive, but if you take care of it, that's unlikely to be an issue. New minis are not super expensive, so probably don't buy a used one unless you are either familiar with them and can do some of the work yourself, or don't mind the gamble/costs for the year and model you really want.

So you may have to spend more on oil changes etc. especially on the turbo models, but the mileage makes up for it....except they're so fun to drive you may not get that 30-40 mpg.

I drive an 11 base Cooper I got from a friend. Her parents bought it for her and she isn't car savvy, but her dad was staunch about her doing the proper maintenance so it's actually in really good shape and only has 68k miles. I don't mind working on the Prince engine (so far). The running joke is that you can technically rebuild almost the entire engine without removing it from the bay. I'm shopping for a new car, but I am keeping the mini for a fun weekend drive/project car. I do open it up from time to time, but mostly keep it under 4k RPM and get around 35 mpg. Mine may be an automatic, but it has the semi-manual option, with sport mode and I can turn of the traction control, so I enjoy it plenty when I want to. I get some looks like "THAT 6' tall guy drives a cooper blasting metal?!" and yeah, it's a bit absurd, but I get my creds back at the auto store because I work on it myself for the basics, doing most of the maintenance right in the parking lot.

comment:
Warning the following comment is classified as "constructive criticism"
It may or may not contain sarcasm, satire or good natured ribbing based upon factual evidence and materials.
Advisory ANY Persons with the slightest sensitivity to hearing the truth, ie: 99% of GenZ, Younger Millennial Snowflakes and highly strung and or thin skinned content creators should only proceed with parental supervision.

Firstly, I should make it clear Ive seen approx 15-20 reviews prior to this one and they were all excellent.

Rather confusingly this review fell well short of my expectations. I'm not some diehard MINI fanboy by any means but I've owned a few different versions of the early series Minis and the R53 Cooper S Manual with a (15% PR ) was my pick of the bunch, it was a real blast to drive, especially with the easy to fit smaller S/C pulley it became a spritely little rocket that left many WRX owner red faced back when they were considered "Fast"

I've seen 10-15 of your reviews and have always appreciated the extra effort that goes into finding and securing a really nice example of the model range your reviewing, however with that said I've gotta ask, WTF happened for this MINI review? I'd really like to know why you just settled on this canary yellow puss box as your feature test vehicle? As far as MINIs go this is about as pox and undesirable as they come.

OK yes I understand it's not a GOLF R or an M3 or something the majority of enthusiasts will froth over, HOWEVER the R50 R52 R53 series MINI COOPER S and JOHN COOPER WORKS have an extremely loyal and super enthusiastic fan base world wide, and dare I say it even the most staunch of V8 diehard car enthusiasts would still find the Cooper S review interesting even if they'd never admit it ü§£

My point is this, I can understand why you wouldn't put much effort into trying to find the nicest example Holden Cruze for example, however these earlier R50 series MINI Coopers are most definitely considered an enthusiasts car and as such they attract plenty of interest. So yes I'm more than a little perplexed by the apparent lack of overall effort when compared to the other 15 odd reviews I've seen from this channel. All the other reviews I've seen the feature car has always been a fine example or even better. But not so for the MINI?

for some reason this MINI COOPER review seemed as if you couldn't care less about it? Seems like zero effort went into this one, I mean seriously you couldn't even be bothered removing the Kmart Seat Covers and that putrid dog ugly steering wheel cover??? I mean cmon bro that's just lazy poor form and it really let the car down, I'm sorry to be so blunt but compared to other enthusiast / special interest cars you've reviewed you really have done the Mini Cooper Dirty in my opinion. Well below your normal high standards.

P.S Toyota YARIS has the most boring bland interior styling but I think putting the Mazda 2 or 3 in the same class is a little unfair, have you never sat in an SP23? I'd argue the Mazda 3 SP23 interior is one of the best designs, Driver dynamics excellent.
Timeless styling and design.
Practical and ease of use.
Funky and Modern style hasnt aged.
The SP23 design is a million times better than any boring ass YARIS my friend üëç

comment:
Absolutely love my 05 Mini S that has the yellow n black color scheme like the one shown in this vid. However, it is a major pain in the @zz working on it. One thing I recommend is to immediately change out the stock coolant reservoir with a metal welded seam aftermarket one. It is notorious for the stock plastic tanks to bust at the seams and if you don't see the overheating warning light, you can quickly blow the engine.... ask me how I know üò°. Also, the plastic clips that hold interior panels as well as the plastic bumper cover, and wheel well shrouds get very brittle and break whenever you work on it. So just pick up a bulk bag of the different types, you'll need them. He's 100% right about the weak doorlock cables and the locking mechanism as a whole. Also, make sure the AC system is functioning properly since it is common for the interior exchanger to get a leak which requires the entire dashboard to be removed just to work on it. (oops, just heard him address this issue).
I disagree with his assessment of space. With the back seats folded down, there's a huge amount of cargo space. Also, the front has tons of legroom, more than I need at 5'11". I only recommend a Mini if you're just absolutely in love with them. Otherwise... look for something else.
Edit: Road noise when driving: I have around a 2000 watt RMS sound system with a 12" sub... so road noise is nonexistent ü§£ FYI, the Kenwood 12" sub with box fits perfectly in the rear cubby and if you have the flap that comes down when you close the hatch, it is completely hidden from the outside. Rockford Fosgate makes a small amp model that fits perfectly in the side panels where the stock one would go. I have one for the main speakers and another for the subwoofer.

comment:
I've got a 2003 Cooper, and have to say your review is kind of fair. When I got mine, it was riddled with issues all dealt with, but since then it's been brilliant. I look after mine that helps, and I think that's true of any car.

Mine has a reconditioned gearbox, the facelift gearbox is better. Exhausts rust at the backbox join. Suspension and tyres should be renewed, and handling improves no end. Oil leaks; check rocker seal. Mine still has the intermittent electric window not working, a rubber mallet takes care of that!

Does it rattle? Yes! Is the ride a bit harsh on London roads? Yes! But is it one of the most fun driver's cars I've driven, even on short trips? Definitely! I love it, flawed but brilliant!

Good review!

comment: Had a '02 for 18 years with the sports package.  Fun car to drive , good on fuel.  In the eighth year,  the power steering failed , Mini knew of the problem,  but did not issue a recall till a year later , and that's typical of BMW . Went through two clutches , 9 hour job , not that I was hard on it , they where short lived , plastic components.  Then windows and locks started to fail . Air bag light was on   $500 for a wiring harness for the seats . Last straw was the shifter cables  , $ 500 just for the cables   had to wait a month for the from Germany.  Overall was a great car  , but never own a BMW product again  , expensive to maintain.

comment: It's well known that the 2005-06 model years are the ones to have. These were the last years of the Gen. 1 cars, and all the problems from the previous years (e.g., the Midlands transmissions in the base cars) were resolved. Most of the other criticisms in this video apply to any other 17-year-old car - some electrical components failing, stiffer suspension, etc. MINIs are all BMW under the skin, and, if maintained properly, are very durable, high-quality vehicles. I've been driving the same MINI since 2005, and I'll never sell it. I do all of the work on it myself, though, and would recommend that anyone who wants an older, "classic" car, knows how to do their own maintenance. Also, never buy one of these with an automatic transmission; these cars are made to be driven.

comment: Mint 2004 R50 here. 2nd owner. 122,000 miles. Other than a first-time clutch replacement at 115,000 miles and a dirty 02 sensor (Cleaned it fix), I‚Äôve had no issues. Average 25 MPG and I‚Äôm really trying to destroy this little clown car, but it just won‚Äôt die. Anybody who assumes these cars are unreliable is just plain wrong or they have neglected to do proper maintenance over the years. I would like to buy another sports car, but this damn thing just won‚Äôt break down and give me a reason to go car shopping. My wife drives a 2019 countryman S all four and it has been a stellar vehicle. Go ahead and buy your Toyotas and Hondas and fall asleep while you‚Äôre driving such boring cars. Believe me, these are much more fun and I love their rally racing heritage. If you are not a car guy, then this is probably not for you and you should stick with something more ‚Äúneutered‚Äù. My wife hates this little car because it‚Äôs such a chick magnet. Every morning when I get up I have to brush off the bras and panties that have been strewn across it in the hopes of getting a lift in this little gem. I can‚Äôt drive past an elementary school without being mobbed by little kids who are overjoyed at the site of this little beast. I‚Äôve lost count at how many times I‚Äôve nearly pissed myself in laughter as hillbillies in giant pick up trucks have flagged me down because their wives/girlfriends insist on getting a picture with this beauty of a car. I wish people would just leave me the fuck alone so that I can drive in peace, but when you wear a size 12 shoe and drive one of the smallest cars on the planet that women adore, well, you probably know what I mean and you just get a lot of attention. Minis for life!

comment: I own one of the unicorns, a 2002 R53 with service records dating back to when it rolled off the lot new, everything has been addressed.  Clutch, AC Fan, Coolant Tank, Supercharger, timing tensioners, Factory recall on Power Steering, and so much more.  It's a great car.  That said, my daily is a 2019 MX-5, but I will note that the MINI is in many ways more fun to drive, but do not have it as primary transport at this age.  Pretty good review, and well done video.  Mine is a grocery getter and my Autocross car, and is great for that purpose, kept garaged and remains meticulously maintained.

It‚Äôs nice to see there are people like you out there who will restore and keep them how they‚Äôre meant to be. Very well done, hats off to you . You should be so proud of yourself for this, it‚Äôs a great achievement. I wish you did repairs for the general public! comment: Got a new Cooper SE a few weeks ago - installed and set up the app on an Android phone (Samsung S10) - worked fine for a week and now it won't even start. Its so dire that I use a Garmin simply because the interface is so much better. Thing you are not understanding with the voltage/wire size thing is that voltage isn‚Äôt a big deal current is. You can use smaller wire at 230 for the same current at 120 for example: 10A at 120V = 1200 Watts. 230V at 5 A is 1200 watts. comment:
Great video. Wiring code is complicated for a DIYer as I found out. Romex inside conduit indoors might be OK, but leaving the plastic sheathing there is also a percentage of volume of the conduit cross sectional area that you can exceed. It's based on a formula and not easy to figure out. Romex can't be used at all in conduit outdoors, wet, or underground. Around my house there is lots of that done by licensed electricians. I stripped out 12/2 Romex from the sheathing and used the wires in conduit for a project. Also not to code. Same as THHN off a spool but not labeled. I heard some manufacturers have the specs on a data sheet that might be accepted. It's all accessible to pull new wire if needed. Where I'm at it's $200 per hour and they don't know when their electricians can get to you. Worry about code later or forget it.

These DYI mini-splits are great, a fraction of the cost. Mr. Cool units I've installed came with 25' lines. That's a lot to string out and avoid coiling, even if just for appearance. A coil looks hokey. Mr. Cool's pre-charged lines is a nice feature but they don't have a DYI 9,000 BTU model. Also, pre-charged lines if they need to be shortened means a lot things to consider well beyond a DIYer. Even 16' lines are a challenge for adjacent bedrooms. I just did 3 with Senville 9,000 BTU units.

comment: You did a ton of stuff wrong on the original video. Why not delete it altogether. So no one sees how to do electrical wrong and burn their house down? You are sizing wiring based off of the voltage and not the amperage! 14/2 is fine for 240v its normally rated for 300v anyways. There should be a Max overcurrent protection written on the tag of the unit. You doubled the amperage. Just because can connect wire and pipes doesn't mean you know anything about electrical. There is no neutral on 240v. And don't put vice grips on brass valves! Leak check the piping connections before you insulate them! Vacuums should never be pulled on time, especially 15minutes. They should be done measuring a digital vacuum gauge! And if you pull the hose off while under a vacuum you have broken the vacuum and allowed air into your system! Woodworking youtubers need to stay away from minisplit installs, they always do it wrong and they are teaching dangerous methods that can ruin your unit and void the warranty.

comment: By the way there is nothing wrong with using smaller gage wire with 240v. In fact, if you compare 120v vs 240v, the higher the voltage, the smaller wire gage you need to transfer the same amount of energy. And this is why we use 240v for appliances that demand a lot of energy, so that you don't need to use enormous and expensive wiring. This is why we use 120v and not something like 12v around the house. This is why we use thousands of volts to transfer electricity over long distances.

Ironically we have had a cooler summer in San Diego so I haven‚Äôt had to run the unit too much but when I do it freezes me out.  My electrician ran THHN inside the conduit, 10 gauge. comment:
What is your issue with using 16Ga for 240V wires?? All that should concern you is whether the wire is rated for the voltage and amperage involved. A 12K BTU mini-split can be run on 120V, typically in the 1500 Watt range, so at 240V it should be only 6 or 7 Amps....very easily handled by 16Ga wire!! In fact, that is exactly the argument for 240V: It lets you carry less current so you can use lighter wires.
No offense intended, but given your several mistakes about the electrical (wire gauge, wiring color codes, and a WAAAY too high breaker, which is both a serious safety concern AND a code violation), you really should not feel competent to be putting up DIY videos that involve electrical.

comment: Your electrical was fine. Any argument that could be made otherwise is negated by the fact that you used much larger wire than necessary. There is nothing wrong with using the white wire in a 240v application. As you now know, 10/2 would have been sufficient since you don‚Äôt need a neutral. If you use 10/2, you have to use white, so no biggie.  If you want, you can throw some phase tape on there, but it isn‚Äôt even required by code according to the last version of the book that I am familiar with. The only argument against Romex in conduit is heat. Since you used a more than adequate size conductor, that won‚Äôt be an issue. Your 30amp breaker was fine too. Circuit breakers are there to protect conductors, not devices. Unless that unit is some really sketchy non-listed hackery, it should have over current protection built into it.

comment: FIRE INSURANCE ‚ÄúCLAIM DENIAL‚Äù!  Everyone should know this!  Failing to have an installation meet Code means, if you have a FIRE and your house burns down, your insurance company can reject the Claim.  When you put in an installation like a moronic schlemiel, the fire inspector will flag it in a hart beat if there is a fire, expect a flood of inspectors. Also, if you go to sell your home the home inspector will likely flag it and then they nit pick everything and you have to finally pay a professional to do it right.  The buyer will also view the house unsafe and it will be a turn off.  All together, electrical work is a profession, not a damn hobby - just like surgery.  Defaulting on your home loans do happen as a result of Code violation electrical fires. Oversized a breaker is the most incompetent thing anyone can do.  It‚Äôs like fools that put pennies behind screw in fuses.  A lawyer who had over a hundred Attourney‚Äôs working for him in insurance company told me, ‚Äúpage one of your policy says they will insure everything except... and the following pages draw lines around craftily worded exceptions‚Äù.  If a properly licensed contractor did the work, the insurance company will commonly pay out, but Subrogate the claim back to the contractors insurance for reimbursement.  People need to wake up that fire is no ...effen.. picnic.  Bankrupt your family and live that up with your in-laws as you live in their basement as the insurance company won‚Äôt even pay for temporary housing.  AND, If you hire someone, be damn sure they are properly license and insured for both commercial general liability and workers comp.  By law in many States, if someone is injured on your property, they have the legal right to file a claim on ‚Äúthe property owners‚Äù homeowners insurance- which is common if they are a subcontractor and have whatever, an $80,000 hospital bill for falling off a ladder or your roof. Obscure, not so.  The hospital bill pay department will coach the injured party. You are screwed and the risk is just not worth it.

comment: Your understanding of the electricity side of things isn't quite right.  Each wire is not "carrying 120 volts."  Each wire is at 240v as the power is traveling through both.  If the power was going from one hot to neutral it measures 120v.  From hot to hot nets you 240v.  You also don't need to "play it safe" and run thicker wire because it's 240v....one of the big advantages of using 240v is not needing thick wire.

comment:
Well Joe... what Fiats do you have then? My first one ws a '76 Fiat 500 R. After that I got a Mini 1100 Special, and a load of others. meanwhile I still have the 500, two Minis (or 2 and a half...), a Fiat X1/9 (and a half), a Ford Capri, a Range Rover V8... and some modern stuff (can a Jaguar S-type be considered a classic?). Maybe we'll soon have the modern Fuiat 500 and the "Bini" too.

comment:
Minis are great fun, closer to a jet powered skateboard than just about any other vehicle. Just about any version is a hoot to drive. In addition one buys into a cult-like ownership experience in which Mini drivers still wave to one another on the highway and drive long distances for annual events. The Mini offers far more configuration options than any vehicle in its class with literally thousands of variations possible in each version. But that configurability comes at a significant cost. It's possible to layer on options that take the MSRP to well over $50,000 for a loaded JCW Countryman.

The $40K MSRP of the model Joe is driving suggests Mini is hoping models with a limited number of popular options will improve sales. And his ad for the local Florida dealer suggesting a $4000 discount from that price illustrates just how dismal the sales figures are for Minis in 2019. In the first four months of 2018 Mini reported sales of all their models to be 14,264. A terrible number that reflects the lowest total yearly sales in 10 years! And 2019 is even worse. This year first 4 month sales are down to 11,532, a 19% drop compared to 2018. (http://carsalesbase.com/us-car-sales-data/mini/)

At $36K, or so the Countryman is not a bad deal versus comparable rivals like the Golf R, the Civic Type R, and what's likely to be the real world price of the Veloster N. That assumes, however, that it's not a loss leader price designed to draw customers into a showroom where they find that the last $36K model was "sold yesterday" but some other more expensive models are still available.

I think MINIs are great cars. But unless the sales declines are reversed I suspect BMW may decide that tradition, funky design, and distinctiveness aren't worth the effort.

comment:
IMO too long despite being "in-depth". Very few wanna watch half hour + car reviews, esp of a mini and it is slightly too repetitive, just the 10-70 mph pulls, there were probabily 20 of practically almost identical one.
Perhaps do a bit more focused, also showing a little bit of 4wd work (nothing special but since it is a Countryman, perhaps a bit of offroading, it would be especially marvelous demonstration if you compare it to a RWD or FWD car and show the advantages of AWD and how they are not only for offroading but how AWD is useful all year, even if only joining a main road from a gravel side road where with RWD or FWD the acceleration/joining will be 5 times slower/less safe due to gravel. Or AWD in rain on asphalt, again uncomparably safe and more planted or faster than 2wd. Portrayal on video would be awesome).
Best videos are those where a viewer can see a comparison to another car to get some basic perspective. Be it 0-60, 50-80 highway pulls, AWD 2WD etc.., suspension/comfort. So few reviewers understand that the best way to convey to viewers is a structured, known format. Like if youre showing comfort level and suspension, include in your videos a stretch of road where you'll be always testing your cars with a few bumps, speed bumps, road inconsistencies/pot holes and then in each video drive a tested car there and compare, maybe show with a glass of water or sth. or an app that shows amplitudes of tremors/shaking. Also app for decibels for cabine noise.
But a 30min video that is very confusing and constantly going back and forth with little coherent head or tail is not the way.

comment:
Black Rose Petal wheels are the very desirable original options especially with polished rims. No racing stripes but Cooper bonnet (hood) stripes are cool. This car should already have the wiring and brackets in for twin spotlights (later cars had four as an option) but if it hasn't forget it. If you want to stop dash rattle fit rubber tube slit on the brackets behind the dash. Some folks use plastic screenwash pipe slit but that can be hit and miss.
Just a tip; Originality is everything on British classic cars and remember that car has a ready market in the UK and they fetch good money in good condition.

comment:
Impressive for 22 years of age. At 19, my first project build was nowhere near this, but it was a race car, not a show car. Although he did say his Mini was more show than go, I think a few adjustments could make it a much more enjoyable car to drive. Sure it looks impressive having a big turbo hanging out the front of the grill, but for a 1.6L V-tech, a GT3076R making 15psi is massive pointless overkill. Not to say this setup isn't capable of it, but at 15psi there's no way that little 16 is making 360hp. More importantly, you don't need a turbo that big to make that kind of power, in fact it's counter productive. That little engine has to wind up to over 5000 rpm to make usable boost, and without proper control, once boost comes on it hits like an on off switch. Listen to this engine wind up and you can hear the instant bump in rpm when it finally gets wound up. In a light little FWD mini that means it breaks lose rather than grips, so controlling that power is paramount. Without control, acceleration suffers, and when it HITS full boost powering out of a corner it becomes seriously hazardous.

With a second gen 2867R you can make upwards of 24psi and start making positive boost under 3K rpm. More importantly, with the right wastegate control and ECU tune, you could have a far flatter power curve and much more linear throttle response. If this youngster did swap turbos, I would strongly recommend not color powder coating the intake turbine as it holds in heat rather than dispersing it. If anything, you could use C-6 Transfer Black coating on the turbine and intercooler to make them more efficient in dispersing heat. Not only does it look cooler than orange, you'd get more respect from people who know what makes real performance. It might be my personal taste, buy it's always bugged me when show car guys degrade high performance parts by using tham as a convis for more bling. It shows a blatant disrespect for what actually makes it cool.

comment:
AWESOME review, guys! Your unbridled joy brought smiles to all our faces!

$150, they're building ten of 'em. Put down your deposits, folks!

But in reality, would you go with this, or an equally fast used Porsche for the same price, or even $50k less (maybe)?

This Mini is badass, but it's a death trap if you don't keep the rubber side down, whereas a modern car can easily save your life if you meet up with a poorly-located tree or light pole. Not an airbag to be found. Crumple zones? Doubt it. A modern sports car offers vastly better safety. Just my $0.02.

Still, what a machine!

comment:
Great review Joe, not too keen on the colour though! I‚Äôm sitting in my home ..in England ...yes it‚Äôs raining as write this!! I would like to confirm the following body parts ( at least from a Uk perspective!) the bonnet is at the front ..what you guys call an hood,. The boot is at the back,. The front sides are wings and under the doors is called the skirts.

The Mini is made in Oxford - middle England. I live south of Birmingham (Brum) in Malvern (Malvern is where the Morgan car is made. - check out their 3 wheeler V8 car!) The Mini was originally made in Birmingham at the Longbridge factory (1959 to 2000) then the dosing and rights to the Mini were sold to BMW. My Uncle worked at the factory and it often says that the Mini was literally given away,. The Uk Government should have stepped in to protect the heritage!

I have owned a Cooper S hatch for 6 years from new and have never had any problems, who says the Mini is unreliable!? This isn‚Äôt true whatsoever, I plan to keep my car indefinitely knowing at some point it will appreciate in price. I am however planning on buying the new manual Mini Clubman JCW 4x wheel drive in British racing green ..in about 4 years time. I am hoping though that Mini have revised the the engine to hybrid and I will be able to plug it in a well as fill her up with fuel.

Keep up the good reviews Joe, I love hearing your thoughts on the Mini.

comment: I'll stick with 5,000 btu window units.  They are cheaper to buy in the winter time, and I keep a brand new one in the box ready to install whenever a window unit finally fails.  No driving to the big box stores in summertime paying a premium for a replacement (if they even have them in stock).  They are easy to handle/install by yourself.  You don't have to cut a hole thru the wall.  You don't have to run a circuit from your breaker box (just plug into an outlet already there near the window).  You definitely don't have to ever call an HVAC company or electrician to do anything.  I got burned by a HVAC company when I bought my house - had them rip out everything existing pertaining to HVAC and install a brand new, state-of-the-art system from scratch.  Paid top dollar for all of this, and had nothing but trouble and fighting with them and the Carrier rep.  Several thousand dollars later and out of warranty, when the coils in the second unit rusted out and I was facing another few thousand dollars to replace it again, I said never again to HVAC companies.

comment: This young man does not have the experience. You can buy a mini split by Mitsubushi with inverter technology, they will last you many years! We had thousands to install and maintain while in Iraq on US military bases. The number one issues we had were keeping the evaporator and condenser coils clean. Also the mother boards go bad on a specific component. These we had to repair ourselves, and a very cheap repair at that! We had many different manufactures of mini splits. The best were Mitsubushi by far. And they were the most expensive, but the electricity they consumed were small compared to the other manufactures. The fan motors would go bad on the off brands, they were sealed motors with no way to oil the bearings. We were in the desert climate. That contributed to this problem. But the main issue was the mother boards. We also learned that the ground to the condenser and cassete wall units must have a frame ground, to both frame units, this helped to prevent burnt component on motorboards! So losing a ground had a detremental effect to many manufactures! So during install, we would have electricians install more grounds. We learned to carry motherboards that had been repaired in our tool bag, any time we had a work order on non cooling, or non heating systems! The instalation of the split systems must be done according to the manufacture instructions. The wall cassette evaporator must hang on wall perfectly level, for proper water drain out rear of unit. Also a proper exact amount of refergerent must be installed. The mitsubushi units had pir technology, so this picks up human movement, once it has picked up this movement, the unit will operate to the predetermined tempeture you had set. Extremely efficent units. Get a liscened installer that has been certified by Mutsubushi. Not just anybody that has a hvac liscense. Mini splits are the way to go. Much cheaper to install, then what this man said. No duct work, no duct cleaning, and think about this, why run duct work in the hottest part of your home the attic!  This is counter intitutive, not common sense. Both major components are easy to get to and maintain. Mitsubushi were some the most quiet units I have ever heard run, I am talking the evaporator fan motor. Whisper quiet.

comment:
I have 2 mini splits in my house.9One in the garage and one in the Arizona Room I built.
The part I don‚Äôt agree, is the COST. I replaced a central, AC compressor for upstairs and a another for downstairs. The cost of replacing the entire system for downstairs (1200 sq feet) cost over 10.000 dollars! I am sold on mini splits since I lived in several countries where this is the only options. A dual split for 2 rooms Dinning & kitchen cost me slightly more than $3000 installed with round ceiling vents! When the other system that is Freon based & about 20 yrs old, Craps out, I will definitely use dual splits or single units. I believe the U.S. ais way behind in taking advantage of this technology, especially now that electricity is expensive & you just need to control the temperature of where you are. Alexa already makes controls to cool down or heat up the areas where you are going to be based on you programming the time when you get home and the time you leave for work.
The only problem I encountered was condescension water dripping inside the garage because the drainage was blocked by a bird‚Äôs nest!

comment:
CON
Many of the mini-splits are DESIGNED ORIGINALLY for ASIAN-ELECTRICAL INFRASTRUCTURE installations. Many appliances and utilization equipment complies with UL Standard UL 101 for MAXIMUM 60 Hz AC LEAKAGE CURRENT of 6 mA. 6 mA is based on human physiology of electric shock susceptibility.

The UL Standards for HVAC, ‚Äúsunsetting‚Äù UL 1995 and the adoption of the European- and Asian-based IEC standard UL 60355-2-40, do NOT test to UL 101 and in fact have leakage current BY INTENTIONAL DESIGN ALLOWANCE as high as a potentially lethal 24 mA (Dakin brand is the worst)!!!

In excess of 6 mA will result in ‚Äúnuisance‚Äù tripping of common Class A GFCIs (ground-fault circuit interrupters). This tripping is NOT the ‚Äúfault‚Äù of the GFCI! The GFCI is protecting you from lethal shock, thank you very much!! The cause is the mini-split having too much 60 Hz UNSAFE LEAKAGE CURRENT by INTENTIONAL DESIGN that is INCOMPATIBLE WITH NORTH AMERICAN INFRASTRUCTURE. NEC¬Æ is forcing UL to revise their UL 60355-2-40 Standard to SAFETY-EVALUATE leakage current in accordance with UL Standard UL 101.

comment: I live in a house built as a weekend place with no central AC system.  It is a two story house and there is no access to add ductwork between floors, either.   We added mini-splits and they work well.  We are on our 3rd or fourth year.    The benefits are to mini-splits is that you only air condition the room(s) you are in and electricity is not wasted on cooling areas you are not using.  They are quiet and do a decent job of humidity removal.   Our challenge is to find a dependable service person for these units.

comment: Our minisplits have thermostats at each head which is not ideal because it only senses the air around the blower. Being multi head we did have a central controller that had to be wired, but thermostat is not in that unit.  Still it works OK when you learn how to use it--the thermostat readings don't mean the same thing as you'd expect. A big factor is that the units can't heat up a room quickly. It is best to keep the units running at an average temperature rather than let the room cool and heat it up. Then you can raise the heat in the room you are in if you like. We've never had ours maintained since we got it (for years)-so no maintenance issue, though cleaning the filters is more a hassle than just replacing one central filter. I'm not sure on comparing costs of installation. It was expensive, but we had to get rid of the rotting (rat damaged) duct work and it's a relief not having those  running  and rotting under our house, collecting dirt from the return air (that's why there are duct cleaning services). Fujitsu. We're happy with it, especially the multi-zone feature. Also we have a practically all-electric house, all covered by our solar PV system. In California coastal so the temperatures are moderate.

Yeah, split copper and condensate tube + cabling needed only. IF Your lucky :) If not then add condensate pump.
But why would You not use a plastic fitting channel SMH, Ofcourse it will be a fugly install with the cabling and piping exposed.
Also for quite a few years now, most consumer market split systems(least the big brands for example daikin, toshiba, mitsubishi electric gree etc.) have had dual thermostat system, atleast as long as night and setback functions have been a thing.

comment: Thought this may help your viewers. I live west of Chicago. Just moved from a big but old house in Aurora that had boiler heat ( no ductwork) to a small house in a small town 12 miles north. Built in the 50‚Äôs it has central heat forced air but had never had central air. Five years ago my mom passed as as we are Canadian living in the US her estate ( plus some procrastination on our part) only is being settled as she had funds and property in both countries. So we have come into some money( not millions) but enough to upgrade our home. Our HVCA company for decades has been Youngrens a family owned business with an impeccable reputation. They do mini splits frequently but almost entirely on new Construcion and old boiler heated homes. He says they are a great way to heat and cool but hard to justify the cost if you already have a high efficiency furnace. In our case we have the quote for just adding AC and it‚Äôs significantly less than the mini split system. Now given the extremes in temp in our area it‚Äôs a very highly regarded Mitsubishi system. However due to the increase in natural gas vs electricity we may go take the plunge. Tough choice.
