comment:
For an up and down duplex I built
I Put the money into extra insulation vs a complicated expensive to buy install and maintain money pit heating system
I Doubled it in the attic R-84 zero maintenance, last forever
2x6 walls with 2:styrofoam on interior and exterior of wall R-46 zero maintenance, last forever
Smaller triple pain glass, single hung so the top window is sealed, and easy as F to put air in there
Baseboard electric heater, of course also avoiding duct work, and can be wired in when the electrician is wiring the house, so minimal cost and heater is about $60.00 , zero maintenance, last 50+ years according to a building I own that was built in 1971 with original heaters
5000 BTU window air conditioner 450 watts is 1/3 cheaper to run about $!30.00 to buy, throw away in 10 years, minimal cost zero maintenance

So $180.00 per room with independent temperature control, and uses less electricity than a split that cost about $3,500 per room where I live,
For the cost of one of these, I doubled the insulation in the whole house
Theoretically cutting the hydro bill in half, if it takes twice as long for heat to escape
I got this simple idea, when I was pouring coffee out of my thermos bottle
To make the hot water tank like a thermos bottle
Then, I thought why not do the house

Cost less to run than this, also avoiding all maintenance, costs and replacement heat pumps and head units , fans etc in the future
Also when a split system fails, everybody has no heat or air
My way they do, just until I get there to trouble shoot one room at a time equals less grief
So, more insulation is a few grand, zero maintenance, last forever
Also, the electric water heater is in a 3'x3' room with 2 x6 insulated walls buried in loose insulation up to over the pipes, and then fiberglass to the ceiling
Of course, I made access panel to the tanks heating elements, and filled them with fiberglass

comment:
I bought a Mr. Cool DIY mini split from Sam's Club March of 2021 and it done great through the summer but it gave out after a couple times of getting frozen rain and snow and ice on it. I was able to take it back since it hadn't been a year and I am a Plus member and the item was covered under a complete satisfaction warranty. I am going to try another one and only use it to cool with but I'm going to go with 2 smaller ones at 12k BTU's instead of a big 18k. I am going to look for something to cover the outside unit during the winter to protect it from the ice!
My 18k 230v unit pulled only 6 amps on heat, so they really are efficient on energy! they have pre-charged lines, so I wonder, also, if part of my problem wasn't just the ice, but that it didn't quite have enough refrigerant in it! I had the outside lines cover with some compact line cover by Pioneer, which really looked nice running down the wall above the skirting rail on my 12' x 60' mobile home. I mounted mine on the wall, and I will not repeat that again. Because event though I had a really good wall mount solid and with the rubber bushing on the feet, it still vibrated the wall enough to be annoying!
I just know I don't want to do a window unit. Because it just looks tacky, in my opinion and they aren't very energy efficient!

comment: My house is hot water heat with baseboard copper piping.  I have a split level house and don't really "live" in the lower so it's divided into two zones.  We live in NE Wisconsin so see REAL winters for at least 3 months out of the year.  Since we don't have forced air, a traditional A/C unit wasn't possible really.  We bought a mini split with heat and it's been great.  It'll heat the upper level when the temp is above freezing, so fall and spring it's the principle source of heat therefore requiring the whole home hot water system to only kick if it gets down to below 20deg at night under most cases.   In the summer it keeps the upper level nice and cool.  Love it.  Best money I've spent in a long time!  Install was very easy,  just had to have an electrician come wire up a box.

Senville is made in Canada and MrCool is made in the USA. Components are made where ever. They are the standard of the world, not America. You can install a mini split in a traditional furnace. They cost less and operate way cheaper than traditional.

These two brands work down to -22‚Å∞ F. Asian units only heat to 5‚Å∞F. Carrier is currently building a plant in NC.

Electric Cars use the same technology to cook and heat.

Nobody is designing new traditional HVAC. But these are hot and only going to get better.

comment: My mobile home has flexible ducts under the home.  Rats can chew through them EASILY... and one did.  Luckily, he couldn't get through the grille of the air register.  However, the rat hole allows large cockroaches to get into my house here in Florida.  I had to go around to EVERY vent register and attach some screening on them so the air can blow in,  but the big roaches can't get through!!!  After doing that,  I haven't seen a single cockroach in 6 months!  Before that, I had 3 or 4 every week walking around my floors like they OWNED the place.  That's why I want a mini-split.  Also those dang air-registers are all over the place right where they are in the way.  One is in the hallway... and it is difficult for bare feet to walk across.  Another one is RIGHT outside the shower... another one is right under the kitchen table where it is in the way of the chair and blows cold air on our legs.  Another advantage is I don't want to cool the WHOLE HOUSE when we are sleeping. Don't need to cool the bedroom when we are all in the front rooms watching TV.  This should cut my energy bill by at least 50%.  By the way,  My old AC unit uses 3000 watts of electricity!  I bet that minisplit only uses about 1500 watts.  But I am just guessing.

comment: Dear Benjamin, I live in northern Mexico, and winters are surely cold here. I installed a cooling-heating mini-split back in 2017, and it has worked nicely, both for heating and cooling. Only once it displayed an error message, after a whole year of use. The error was E8, and in desperation, I thought I had made a poor investment, however, an idea hit me an I simply cleaned the mesh filters at the air input in the indoor unit. Worked like magic! It worked nicely again. What I do ever since is to clean them with a dry brush every year, and no problem whatsoever. My opinion is minisplits are great, and highly efficient in both functions. I even took my natural gas bill down by 90 per cent! Another bonus is the water coming out from the outside unit in summer and spring I use it for watering my trees and garden, thus lowering my water bill as well. Thanks for your very interesting and useful video!! I almost forgot, I installed some solar panels on my roof, and my light bill is also very small, in spite of having two minisplits now, plus two electric water boilers.

comment: I had a Mini Split System installed in my home 2 years ago. I had 4 units installed, 3 9k/1 18K Mitsubishi MLZ Ceiling cassettes cause I didn't want to see wall units  in every room, or the holes in the wall. I do have a wall unit that I purchased used that cools off my entire basement. After 3 yrs it was low on freon and I had to top it off, otherwise its never given me any issue. I'm having a 4th 9K installed in a couple of days for my kitchen. I installed it over a conventional system because I saw no purpose in air conditioning bedrooms that were unoccupied all day, most days, or cooling an empty living/dining room all night. When there's no one home, the CAC is off I've had zero increase in my electric bill. I LOVE my system and how it works. When its bed time I turn off the Living room unit and turn on the bedroom unit. At 1st I'd turn it on 5 mins before I went to bed to cool off the room. I stopped doing that because cold air comes out with 20-30 seconds of turning on and cools the room in 3-5 mins. the units are whisper quiet. Even though my system provides heat, I prefer to use my gas heated cast iron baseboards in the winter. So far I am 100% satisfied with my mini split system.

comment:
Excellent review. Go figure that these systems are built overseas! What isn't? I guess cost to the customer would be greater if these units were made in North America. Profits to big corporations and nice dividends to investors is first and foremost.
I am hoping to be building a small cottage in the next few years and I have been racking my brains about what type of heating and cooling system to install. Because we are located in central Ontario on Lake Huron and that our setting is rural, my options are this unit, in-floor heating that is operated via propane, a conventional system with duct work or electric baseboards.
With electric baseboard heat and with the soaring cost of electricity in Ontario, it is the least favoured option. Then I would have to install portable ac units. If I opt to go with an in-floor heating system, then I won't need a basement or a crawlspace thereby saving me money on construction costs. A lot of people in my area have had this type of system installed and say how great it is for even distribution of heat. floor temperatures at 65 deg. feels like 70. I haven't got feedback yet about cooling in the summer months though. If your building is well insulated, you might not need to install ac.
I think the conventional system is self-explanatory. Nowadays, furnaces are much more compact and extremely efficient upwards of 98%, so it still hasn't been ruled out. I will have to compare total costs.
This has been a good starting point to get feedback on this type of system. Thanks for sharing it with us. Cheers!!

comment:
just got a massive double 48,000 BTU Mitsubishi Hyper heat system installed in my home. 8 heads total. it's an old farm house that has a horrible and inefficient propane furnace system. because of the ineffective way the duct work was installed (3 out of the 4 bedrooms upstairs have no ductwork at all), i was paying $1000 a month in propane bills. I live in Upstate NY and the winters can be nasty.

I just had this system installed and now i have heat in every room. No doubt my electric bill will go up but my main goal is to make the biggest dent possible in that propane bill. plus i have the nice bonus of central AC which i've never had in my life.

it made sense to me because of the way the house is and the fact it's propane. If it was natural gas it may not have been worth it. Even if i cut the propane bill in half ($500/month) the system will pay for itself in 5 or so years.

comment: Carrier is a US brand for minisplits and probably one of the best.  Yes, there are a lot of other than US brands but most are okay.  I lived on Guam for most of my life and they do well.  A lot less expensive than here in the mainland.  I'm not sure why it costs so much to install here and the unit cost is pretty crazy.  I guess it's supply and demand.  I am no expert for sure but I did like the splits.  We usually only had them in our bedrooms because that is where we spent most of our time when we were home and it doesn't get cold or even cool on Guam.  It's either warm or hot and always beautiful.  We had concrete home so when we had condensation issues we just cleaned them up and cleaned the unit.  Here in California it might be a different issue with all the wood.  Call Carrier on Guam and ask them if you have questions or even Trane (sorry I forgot about them).

comment: I noticed you talked about the ability to cool multiple zones differently. I think it's important to note that if you're like me, the esthetic is not nearly as important as the ability to properly cool and heat rooms in my home. I live in Texas about an hour east of Houston, in a modular home. The original ac barely made 10 years, and was terrible for efficiency and effective heating and cooling. In the past seasons my family suffered due to overheating and cooling in certain parts of the house, and no ability to heat and cool the rest. Ducted systems lose effectiveness the farther you get from the unit, so my daughter got blasted being one room away from the unit, while my wife and I got nothing hardly at all, being on the other end of the house. While it is true, the bigger full central air units may last longer, they're not bulletproof, they're very expensive, and almost always require professional support when it comes to any maintenance beyond the filters. The smaller mini split units are simple, and can be installed by the diy guy in most cases. An hvac expert should be called when vacuuming the system, but that's about it. With mini split units, one doesn't have to heat or cool all the individual rooms in the home, which is much more efficient. I'm a proponent of multiple single zone units, and for one reason. With multiple single zone units, if a unit does go down, I still have the ability to heat or cool other units in my home. As far as price goes... well I try to look at the big picture. Ducted systems seem cheaper at first, but I found when looking at the bigger picture, it ends up being more cost efficient with the mini split unit, even if it doesn't live as long as the central air unit. That being said, this is a question of the home owners needs and preferences. Either solution can be useful, but for me, I choose the mini split. Oh and just like anything else, price often comes down to the owner. I just purchased a mini split system for my master bedroom and bathroom, and found it to be very affordable... much much cheaper than replacing my entire unit which require changing both the outdoor unit, and the indoor unit as well as all the lines. The bigger unit may be cheaper for others who would not have to replace both units. But the unit I purchased is cheaper than any descent hvac unit available. And no I didn't buy the cheapest unit out there. I can't afford the best units, but I've found that many times a good middle of the road unit provides great value. It's still a quality unit, and it can be affordable for those of us with limited budgets. All invested, my unit will come in at about $1200.00 completely installed and running. This comes with me doing all the install, and the electrical work. An hvac specialist will be called to pull the vacuum on the installed unit. That's much better than the $4000.00 -- $6000.00 minimum I was quoted for replacing my old system. Now keep in mind that I would have to spend significantly more if I decide to do multiple units, but even then the cost still comes up less when you consider the efficiency over several years use. Thanks for the video

comment: THIS IS A GREAT VIDEO.... I have a house with dual central air/heat 18 years. The two ac/gas furnace units are getting tired. We have +90F days (Heat index +100). My AC does OK but on really hot humid days I can't keep the 73F inside temp. It creeps up to 76 downstairs and +80 upstairs. Up stairs is over the garage bonus room with full bath. I am planning replacing my up stairs central air with a mini split. I got a quote. I was going to have to do SO MUCH WORK with electricity, structural penetration and drain it was not worth it. The quote I got was high and assume I provided all the electrical, drain and structural pentation. The DOWN side is being on the second floor you have to mount the outside condenser unit at ground level (or low enough to access standing on ground).  If I could mount it at 2nd floor level it would be better. However it looks like replacing the central air/furnace is the way to go.  I traveled in Asia several times for business and vacation and mini split is common. I like them especially for the situation I have over the garage with one big room. However after looking at this video, and getting the high quote (where all they did was run the lines and mount the units, with electrical and refrigerant line penetrations done) it is a no brainer. I will replace the central air/gas furnace.  BTW the gas furnace works like a champ.... but we have fairly mild winters. A mini split Heat Pump might be in play in the garage, since the hook up would be easy DIY....

comment: I have 2 mini splits installed on out buildings one on my shop 800sf and another on wife's she shed 200sf. I live in AZ the HOT part, these things are amazing. My shop stays at 80 degrees, it is metal yes it is insulated but the doors can not be at this time. Luckily they face north and I can keep some foam board insulation sitting behind them for now but my 24000 btu Daikin unit doesn't even struggle to keep up. When it is 115 plus out I can kick it down to 70 if I want too with no problem but lets face it when it is that hot out I might catch a cold at 70. So far my electric bill has not even suffered from them units being installed yet either. If they continue to perform this well when the time comes to replace the main house unit I will most likely go with a few mini splits plus lets face it if something does break at least you do have more than one unit in the house. I disagree with the over cost as well I have priced out standard units vs minis and the mini are cheaper plus the fact I can do most the installation myself that is even more savings. Than you add the long term electric saving over the operating life I think it become even more or a no brainer. Plus the fact you can eliminate the old air ducts and no more maintenance on them nothing but wins with mini splits the way I see it. I do wish a US company would step up and start manufacturing them than it would be a complete win win.

comment:
Hmmm. Ducting wastes up to 33% of your HVAC energy, depending on the design of your house. We have a single level, 3000 sq ft home (all-electric). The ducting is entirely in the attic and the insulation on this (flexible hose) ducting is R8. That's where the 33% calculated losses came from. Living in Arizona, attic temperatures routinely exceed 140 deg F. As our home was built 15 years ago, the HVAC units (2 of them) are rated at SEER 14. Our units have proven very reliable, but that's because we run our system at 80 deg F - most people choose a lower temperature which means the HVAC units run harder (and die earlier). Most of our neighbors (in a 15 year old community) have had to replace their central units.

Configuration: So then, I installed mini-splits into all our enclosed rooms (bedrooms, offices). We retained a single unit to cool the open areas but brought ALL the ducting inside the cooled space. The mini-split systems (5 of them) were brought under computer control so, for instance, bedrooms are cooled ahead of bed-times and allowed to drift higher during the day. The system is linked to Alexa so we can even phone-in commands on the way home.

Price: The TOTAL cost of our 5 mini-splits was under $5,000. They are Panasonic and Mitsubishi (prices have risen as mini-split popularity is beginning to take off). Total peak capacity was 7 ton. This eliminated an existing 5 ton HVAC unit. When we priced upgrading our central unit to SEER 21 (which required replacement of both the head unit (in the attic) and the outside compressor) the cost, including installation, came to $15,000 (give or take). That was the CHEAPEST quote we got from Valley HVAC suppliers. This did not include improving the attic ducting to reduce thermal losses in the system. Our mini-splits vary, but are rated between SEER 19 and SEER 23.

Control. The computer system which runs the mini-splits is a small Raspberry Pi Cloud to eliminate single-point-of-failure - I designed and built the system myself. It has infrared cameras in every room that allow the computer to learn patterns. The same system also acts as a fire alarm and the system can calculate best egress path which in the event of fire is communicated through floor lights and voice. The system also acts as a self-arming home alarm system. The entire control system, including cameras, came to $2,500.

Noise: When our house was built (track home) the HVAC units were positioned between two bedrooms. They system was always incredibly noisy whereas the mini-splits are almost inaudible. I would rate the switch to mini-splits, especially for the affected bedrooms, to be a major advantage of mini-splits. They are simply much, much quieter. Of course this was a consequence of indifferent, indolent home design but it's a problem I've seen many times.

Endurance: The units I bought are common-place in Europe, the Middle East and Far East. You see the American solution almost nowhere when you travel because it is expensive, hard to retrofit and a maintenance nightmare (especially in the Middle East where houses are often extended vertically over years). I talked to many HVAC engineers in the Middle East (Egypt, Jordan, Syria) and the consensus was that modern mini-splits are good for 20 to 25 years. Come back in another 15 years and I'll tell you how I'm doing! To date, none of our units have failed. They are easy to keep clean (because the head unit isn't in the attic)

Redundancy: So we have 5 mini-split systems. This means if any one unit fails the rest continue and we maybe lose a bedroom or office while the failed unit is replaced. However this compares favorably to the nightmare situation where a central HVAC system fails in the middle of an Arizonan summer (temperature today in June is expected to hit 118 deg F). We own several rental units and when the HVAC fails we are obliged to move tenants into a hotel until the system is working! Of course summer is peak-demand on HVAC technicians so expect delays of up to 2 weeks if the entire system needs replacing! This makes mini-splits a highly advantageous solution if, like us, you are cooling individual rooms (or maybe two rooms with multiple head units) since you can always retreat to the remaining cooled rooms should there be a failure. We intend to retrofit ALL of our rental units.

Quality of life: I like to run our workout room and offices at lower temperatures - both are brought to a cooler temperature either on a routine or on demand. We can do this without cooling the rest of the house and wasting energy. We've found that mini-splits allow us to have a much more comfortable experience at home (especially in the covid era) while saving money!

Disadvantages: Really there are just two. First, there is likely a need to run additional wiring. Removal of one central HVAC unit gave us a good 220V supply on one side of the house but we needed to add another 220V, 40A run on the other side of the house. I am an electrical engineer so this wasn't a problem for me, but electricians are ludicrously expensive (the minimum quote I got from a professional was $1,700 for a single run down the side of our house). Second, there is the problem of finding appropriate locations for the outside units which do not hinder passage (down the sides of the house) and do not look ugly. As a retrofit this require a lot of thought and careful design - in some cases a reasonable solution may be impossible. Sorry! Another disadvantage was the quoted installation costs from HVAC companies - they wanted more to install the systems than the systems actually cost! That could be just an Arizona phenomena but I was shocked by the money they wanted (something like $1500 per unit excluding electrical wiring). So I simply did it myself. To help out I bought a two-stage vacuum pump, gauges and a nitrogen tank (welding supplies) so I could thoroughly test the system for leaks then prepare for the released of the refrigerant (which is held inside the compressor when shipped to your house). Once I was satisfied there were no leaks, all you do is open a valve and the system is ready to use!

Operating costs: Based on 5 years experience (6 in November) the mini-split solution has more than halved our HVAC energy usage, with corresponding savings on our electric bill. I estimate the entire system, including the control system, will completely pay for itself in less than 8 years. This makes mini-spits a far better investment than solar (although we have that too) while improving quality of life. In our case we installed mini-splits as our existing central systems approached end-of-life (which in Arizona is roughly 15 years for the Goodman units installed in our community). So the cost was actually much, much cheaper than installing a new SEER 21 central solution.

Summary: In my opinion, attic ducting should be made illegal in hot-climate States (especially Arizona). All ducting should be designed to run within the cooled space. That's an immediate 33% saving here in Arizona. The design of mini-split systems COULD be improved. I would like to install pressure and acoustic sensors, ammeters and fan speed monitors in order to predict failures and provide accurate diagnostic information on a real-time basis. Also, getting the information to put the mini-splits under computer control was not easy - very few manufacturers were willing to cooperate with me. I can't explain why since this would surely allow them to sell more 'solutions' to American homes. If I were to design a new home it would most likely be a hybrid system because cooling large open areas with mini-splits is highly problematic. I would certainly be more careful about positioning the external unit (away from living areas) and all ducting would be inside the cooled spaces of the home. I would design-in locations for the mini-splits so they are not an eyesore. If I do retain a central air unit, it will be located inside the living area rather than the attic. Service technicians are human too - they don't like crawling around in attics in the middle of summer!

At the very least, if you watched this video, you may be considering using mini-splits for bedrooms or offices. If so, I can tell you that mini-splits are a great option. If you are a competent (and somewhat brave) DIY'er then you can reasonably tackle this project yourself. Make sure, ahead of time, that you know what is needed in terms of power. Although you can buy some 110v solutions, I'd recommend 220v and running new wiring as-needed. You need to check your fuse box has spare slots and that you do not exceed the capacity of the box in terms of current. You must duct external wiring (code) and require a disconnect box (also code). We have a 200A fuse box which worked out perfectly. Note that electricians are rip-off merchants - many think they can charge $150 to $220 an hour for labor whereas I wasn't prepared to spend more than $50 to $70 an hour. HVAC technicians? It depends heavily on finding a 'tame' technician who offers realistic prices. For our rental units we have such a person but it took us 10 years to find him! To-date none of our mini-split systems have failed. Cleaning filters is fast and easy, so it's become something we do every month. For our central unit, I installed a pressure sensor which can precisely tell us when it's time to change the filters (why aren't ALL houses fitted with this solution?).

comment:
Something which the US is lagging on is "Inverter" air conditioning technology. I discovered it in Mexico while building a vacation home. In fact, no one down there buys the old technology because all it takes is 2-3 months of electricity savings, and you already have re-couped the 15-20% difference. Inverter tech has also started to be incorporated into refrigerators and microwaves in many countries. I've seen a 30-50% decrease in my electricity bill over the past 18 months. After problems with my original HVAC, I went and got 4 split system units. I no longer heat my whole house. I only heat the rooms we use when we're using them.
The biggest bonus with Inverter Split Systems is they are whisper quiet. Unlike traditional HVAC thermostats, which turn on when a certain upper/lower temp is reached and turns off when a certain upper/lower temp is reached, Inverter technology slows down the compressor and the fan speed of the wall-mounted unit. It maintains the specific temp I choose to set it at. Finally, yes, all split systems are made outside the US, but four brands are superior. Mitsubishi, Bosch, LG, and Daikin (which owns Goodman). The rest are all generically made and then rebranded, so tracking down parts requires you often to find a supplier of the same unit (but called something else) and obtain parts through them. My neighbors in Mexico have 5 rebranded split system units (Mirage) for 7 years, and they haven't had to do anything except clean a filter that cleans the air and prevents stuff from getting on the internal heat/cold exchanger. The physics behind the efficiency comes down to two things. A compressor that stops and then restarts uses 3 times the current. And secondly, because there is virtually no noise from the compressors on the roof or the units on the walls inside, there is minimal energy wasted in the form of noise.

comment: Those mini splits are cool, (no pun intended). A 20 x 24ft garage is not small. I can see yours is insulated well, but no drywall. A decent window unit would have done the job. Yes you have to cut a hole and frame it in, but costs much less. Believe me, the m/s is super nice for that application. There is controversy whether it is better to have a little under or over in btu because of dehumidifying. I prefer a little over because the bigger unit moves more air, which means it is dehumidifying more volume. Cool it on down so it can shut off, instead of running forever and costing a fortune in electricity.

I think its worth mentioning that its not the minisplit itself that has higher maintenance costs. That's Modern air conditioning based on electronics. In europe we have been using these systems for 20+ yrs and only use inverters or VRFs also for ducted air conditioning so that's a caracteristichs of newer evectronic systems. It is also true that from those electronics you also get an enormous cost reduction for running the system, and by using a daikin or mitsubishi system the probability of it going bad is very low, and you get very high build quality.
Its true that with traditional systems you can carry everything in the van and repair all ACs, but how it is done here every company is specialized on a brand, and it has all the components for the brand, it's just the market has to adapt to it.

comment:
Mini Splits have much higher energy efficiency than traditional HVAC systems, and they combine heat and A/C in a much more compact unit. Most Mini Split systems have a SEER rating of 20-25, and while traditional HVAC system can reach 22 SEER, the bulk of them are rated at 14-16 SEER, with the higher rated SEER units costing much more, to the point where very few are sold. Combine this with the room-zoned capabilities of Mini Splits compared to the larger zoned HVAC systems, and the energy cost savings can more than make up for their shorter lives.

The increased efficiency of Mini Split heat pumps, makes them economically competitive with natural gas heating, and negates the need for gas lines and a furnace system.

comment: I really like them, but I'm not in HVAC and the building I use it in has no ducting. I haven't seen any issues with mine running like 6yrs now I think. Mine is a MrCool. It is sized to where it came precharged so you didn't have to do anything but hook it up yourself. Also when I got it, just like with most anything I buy, I get parts tools filters batteries etc that I will need for maintenance or repairs. I know how to do electrical and that was standard and easily replaceable. The lines are easily recharged yourself (if you have the tools). Looked pretty standard... granted nothing has gone wrong knock on wood so I've not had to get all up into every piece... but I don't see anything that wouldn't be easily replaceable if I needed someone else to fix it... but yeah, just way more cost effective and efficient than standard window units. And with heaters too. I think the whole system, mount, wire cover panels (decorative), and tools parts materials needed came out to around $2k. Buying a window AC this efficient and a heater this efficient plus tools parts materials to repair & maintain them if needed would be about the same, but take up way more space. And would have to be installed and removed often whereas this stays year round in it's spot. The separate units might last this long, but not be as efficient year after year... Also, it is WAYYY cheaper to run and my electric bill is fine. I know lots of folks with the big whole house units and they are super hot or super cold because it costs too much money to be reasonable. I think it is way cheaper to cool or heat what rooms you are in than to try to pretend that you can efficiently and cheaply heat or cool your entire house. But yeah, my space is small so a big unit like that doesn't make sense anyway which is why I compared smaller units. I think it's better, but that is just my opinion based off a smallish space and this specific appliance. One thing that my location might impact too, I'm in MN as well, is that this is not my only source of heat and nothing in the price range or size would be adequate. My wood stove does most of the work and this just keeps things a bit nicer if I don't want to get up and stoke & feed the fire for a longer sleep ;) This is more a backup heat wise and so more an AC unit only for me. If this one ever dies, I might buy a bigger one that I have to charge before using now that I know how and have the equipment to do so. But yeah, hope that helps. And again, I'm just a random DIYer and not an HVAC professional.

comment: I live in Europe, where as you said, the duct type are very rare, almost exclusively in commercial sector. Also the're quite cheap and reliable, people are changing them because of the newest inverter advantages. But surprisingly your video hasn't pointed out the upmost inconveniences with the split type, and the reason I am looking to buy the duct type: 1) a lot of cold air is coming from a small split and this creates temperature inequalities inside the room which creates discomfort. 2) they need constant cleaning as they accumulate more easily dangerous bacteria and dust on their very small filters. 3) they tend to get noisy because they have to process a lot of air over a small transfer surface. 4)You can't get natural ventilation with them. So my main issue with the split type would be the fact that the heat exchange is happening on a too small fan coil and the air is running too fast from them making them quite inconfortable.

comment: Probably the biggest disadvantage I've seen about mini splits in the US from a repair standpoint is that you'll get inverter drive board failure in the outdoor unit after the reactor has failed especially in salt air climates near the coast. Same thing also happens to the reactors from a lack of clean consistent AC voltage during peak electrical usage in the summer. Neither of which is really a fault of their design, but a product of growing population density along the coast and a lack of infrastructure for cleaner energy production and transmission. One can always consistently argue that nothing today is designed and built to last like systems of old. Perfect example is the older refrigerant systems used copper tubing with a much thicker wall because copper back then was much cheaper. Over time as the cost of copper has risen all system manufacturers of coils that utilize copper has seen a decrease in the tubing wall thickness to the point where coils were no longer lasting till the end of manufacturer warranty periods. At this point most have changed from a design point and switched to primarily aluminum designs. On a side note, all manufacturers of residential equipment specifically state in their warranty information that none of their equipment is designed to be used during the construction or remodel phase of a home. They further state to do so voids their warranty. It's not primarily because of dust and debris with the exception of drywall and ceramic tile dust, but because of the out gassing of volatile organic compounds (VOC's) from all the building materials and adhesives used in construction. It attacks the indoor coils at the molecular level and compromises their integrity and intended longevity. You can't prevent that with high capacity media filters or electronic air cleaners. Now before you begin to argue job security let me tell you this. As an individual who has worked in the field performing service, maintenance, repairs, and installs for fifteen years now, my time is just as valuable as anyone else. I'd rather better maintain the equipment by addressing potential problems during annual scheduled maintenance and nurture my customer's relationship knowing that I've effectively reduced the chance that my contract customers require after hour service whilst I'm on call! And because you invested that time in nurturing that relationship during preventative maintenance, you build trust that helps later down the road when it does come time to address equipment replacement. It doesn't matter what equipment you buy. It's only as good as the quality of the workmanship that installs and maintains it. That to me is the ultimate job security. It keeps your customers happy which means repeat business and free word of mouth advertising based on your integrity. Businesses seem to forget that consumers will pay for top notch professional service when they are treated fairly and you keep them informed. Your customers AND your employees are NOT disposable. Just consider how much MORE it costs to retrain quality employees or how much MORE it costs to acquire new customers versus taking better care of the ones you have. It's a win/win for everyone:   customer, employees, and business!

comment: When you have serious demand for cooling and heating, the mini-splits seem underpowered compared to a quality standard. They also seem to draw a lot of electricity compared to standard AC units. I just installed a 2-stage Trane unit and on its high stage (the 2nd stage) it was drawing  19 amp, and this  is the maximum draw from the unit because the house was very hot. After the house was cooled down, the unit ran in Stage 1 for the rest of the month, which is at 70% capacity or 13.3 amps. I just saw a mini-split video and the electricity draw to run an 1800 BTU Mr. Cool mini-split for a garage was 6.7 amps. So my Trane central AC was cooling the ENTIRE house and it only used about 6 amps more than the mini-split. My house is 1850 SF and it is in AZ where it is very hot. It was a 104 degrees F outside and my Trane unit easily kept the house at 79 Degree F (which is the set point that is comfortable for me).  The mini-splits just don't seem to be a good value. My Trane unit includes a brand new, efficient gas furnace, which will also save me money in the winter and the entire unit cost $8,340.00 installed with a 5-yeawr warranty for labor and a 10 year warranty for materials.  Trane is the most reliable AC brand in Consumer Reports and they use top of the line components. The mini-splits don't seem to be built nearly as well.

comment:
My first mini split experience. Just built two cabins for a youth camp, 800sf.
Installed in each cabin:
18K BTU condenser and two 9K BTU heads inside.
Less than a month after we turned over the cabins to the owners we get a call that the AC is out on both cabins???
Sent tech out, both circuit boards and noise boards are out, need replaced.
Out on a Wednesday, tech on Thursday, ordered parts, installed new boards on Monday.
Installed surge protectors on each condenser AND a surge protector on each cabin.
Three days later on Thursday the boards are out again.
This was the third week of July.
We again ordered new circuit and noise boards. Noise boards still not available anywhere in the world 4 months later???
Had a meeting with the technical rep for the manufacturer of the equipment and three engineers from the power company.
Power company claims lightning took out the units.
We built on Helical piers, https://www.piertech.com/ , and power company claims the piers, 15 per cabin at a depth of 15' to 20' were attracting the energy from nearby lightning strikes, the energy them migrated from one of our piers to the ground rod of the electrical panel, fed backward through the panel box and fried the circuit boards.
Through the coarse of the meeting they all said that they do consistently bring power to the meter ay 250-258 volts. Operating range for our mini splits is 240-245 volts.
They suggested we install step transformers on each condenser.
AC equipment supplier will not warranty anything, lightning claim.
They are willing to credit one 18K BTU condenser not for warranty but to study the affects of the energy surge.
AC suppliers recommendation is to remove the 2-18K BTU condensers and install 4-9K BTU condensers, one for each head inside
OR
Remove the entire system and install a package unit designed for mobile/modular homes since we are off the ground 24"
We consulted 5 lightning protection companies and all are not buying the story about the energy moving from one of our helical piers to the ground rod of the panel box.
All 5 said the purpose of lightning rods is to get the energy to the ground.
We had 2 companies quote installing lightning rods on the cabins and an additional quote to grounding all of our piers together.
All of this keeps coming back to my pocket, at great expense.
I would welcome any and all ideas and suggestions anyone could offer.
We are presenting the findings of all this info to the youth camps next week.
Even if you think you don't have all the answers, any ideas or suggestions would help.
When we contacted the helical pier company they said they have not had any issues like this.
In fact, helical piers are used extensively on solar panel farms due to their speed of installation.
Feel free to contact me at
furnivalconstruction@gmail.com
Ron 321-684-2270
Thanks!

comment:
Thanks for the video. Very useful information.

Some additional important points about ducktless mini split systems.

These systems are only good choices as primary heat for extremely well insulated dwellings with excellent double/triple glazing. These systems are good choices as only supplemental heat source for dwellings with not ideal insulation and glazing.
Some of the reasoning:

1. heating testing is done at around 40 and 20F. Lower values are extrapolations. Below 20F the efficiency drops drastically. This can be seen in the graph starting around @.

2. costs are higher than oil heat, unless [state] electricity costs are very low.

3. Heat is expelled from the head at the ceiling and must be pushed down to the living space by the weak fan. This will not be [efficiently] successful because heat rises and the "whisper quiet" fan is not sufficiently powerful to overcome the thermal forces and other heated air distribution issues.

4. Heat sensor is in the head at the ceiling where the temperature is much higher than at the center height of the room, or at the floor. Therefore, comfort is a great challenge. A $250 programmable thermostat for each head is a must.

5. Well skilled/educated contractors [in heat pump technology] are extremely difficult to find. Without a well skilled designer/installer, the project is a failure "waiting to happen". Buyer beware!
6. Mechanical noises are annoying and distracting. Vibration noises from outside units will be present if the outside unit[s] are mounted on the exterior wall.

comment: I have 3 split units. I have central ducts as well running in the attic in 150 degree heat. 2 splits are Mitsubishi. I do my own maintenance. I had service provider come out and charge 200 for recharge and 300 for cleaning. Learn my lesson that service providers charge more and they don‚Äôt provide the correct procedures. Guessing on how much recharge it needs instead of vacuuming the system pressure test and reweighing the freon charge back in. The fan gathers fluffy content on the blades and stops airflow being one of the important considerations when the system become inefficient. The best consideration I see is how financially economical running mini splits instead of central air. My electrical cost has dropped 2/3 of what I was paying with central. With central units now taking on redesign following the efficiency of mini splits the electrical cost usage has gotten better.  However the unit price has gone up. I prefer mini splits. Low cost to run and independent efficiency in each room. Mine are 9 years and still running well.

comment: I installed 3 of these systems in my home after going through multiple window units (LG SUCKS!!!). I've had the split units for about 14 months now, so far so good. They are "Confort" brand which I've never heard of so, I was extremely hesitant to install them but I couldn't pass on the price of the units or the install charge. The only thing I was a little confused on was the installer stating they could run on either 110 or 220. I don't know the first thing about electrical and I hate messing with it. I opted for the 110 so I could simply plug into existing wall plugs (each on their own breaker) and to avoid having to pay someone to install 220 lines. They're 1200 BTU in rooms that are roughly 132 square foot each so, needless to say, they help heat and cool the rest of the home. Again, so far, so good...fingers crossed.

comment: I was first introduced to the mini split concept in an episode of Norm Abram's New Yankee Workshop tv show many years ago.  The unit he installed was a Mitsubishi and I think they may have been the first in the US market and pretty expensive too.  Norm did not spend a lot of time talking about the mini split and went on with his woodworking project, but the idea continued to rattle around in my brain.  Several years later I built a 1000 sq ft garage/workshop for myself and made provisions for a mini split line set to go through the wall plus put in the outside electricals for the compressor.  Six hot, miserable summers later I was ready to pull the plug on a mini split, during the winter I did a lot research and determined that 24,000 btu would do the trick and selected a Friedrich brand unit.   I installed it myself, but had an HVAC tech check my work and was on hand at start up to check for leaks, add refrigerant if needed and operation.  That was in May of 2013 and have been very pleased with my decision.  I do not use it for heat as I had put in radiant heat in the floor.  The unit has been trouble free (knock on wood) and sips electricity, helped by a well insulated building.  That said, I cannot imagine using a mini split in my residence.

comment:
Firstly, thanks for doing this video - and all other previous videos. I enjoy watching all of them. Here are the additional minisplit pros and cons from my personal experience...

Pros:
(Electrical) One technical advantage that nobody mentioned: Many minisplits today use inverter technology. So they don't spike your electrical system - if you have a standby generator, you don't have to worry about "starting current". Current slowly ramps up and stays exactly at the required level. So if your generator is not super large, you won't need to worry about voltage drops that results in lights dimming when then AC "kicks in" - which inverter systems never do. On a traditional system, you need the hassle of installing a "hard start capacitor" to try to minimize this effect. Also, you don't need to size your generator to run ACs for your whole house ($$). Just the rooms/zones you need. Sidenote - inverter systems also results in "variable tonnage" feature on minisplits. So a 1 ton system might be cooling at a constant 1/2 ton capacity if the room is sufficiently cooled already.

(Ambient noise) An inverter system minisplit these days run almost silent. You cannot hear the compressor at all. You can only hear the whooshing sound of the condenser fan.

(Air distribution) Many minisplits come with at least an up/down auto swing air vent - some with left/right swing as well. You can set your desired directional cooling or cooling a room more evenly.

(Electrical) You do not need a dedicated line running from the breaker box if you are running a smaller unit (up to 12,000BTU or 1 ton) - which you could just branch off from a 120V outlet.

(Efficiency) The best SEER rating on minisplits in the market is rated at some crazy 42 SEER, typical minisplit of a reasonable price range hovers around 19-22 SEER whereas standard whole house units typically are rated at much lower SEER.

(Cost) Other advantage, you don't need to cool the WHOLE HOUSE if you only need to have one or two rooms cooled. This reason alone saves a ton of power, and hence utility bills. Plus, with Wi-Fi Alexa/Google control available with many systems, you can even remotely cool individual rooms from your phone or with your voice.

(Cost) A replacement coil in your standard system - including labor could cost $2,000. A replacement of an ENTIRE inside unit of a minisplit is under $300 for the part - and no brazing is required.

(Cost) Most minisplits use washable air filters, which you can even use a vacuum to clean. No more expensive throw away air filters.

(Cost) Minisplits are so easy to install that some companies are selling systems meant for DIY install that a typical weekend handyman can do. No HVAC installer needed. Good for the home owner, bad for the HVAC tech.

(Cooling) Also, even if you have a standard system in your home, there might be a room or some corner of the house where it's ALWAYS warmer - because moving air through ductwork doesn't always guarantee even cooling of every corner of the house. Adding a single zone minisplit in those areas will solve that problem. Also serves as an "emergency system" when your main system goes down!

(Cooling) And obviously, if you have multiple minisplits spread out in every room of the house, if one minisplit goes down, the other rooms are still cooled, so you won't need to have put a "rush emergency repair" $$ call to the HVAC company. Parts may take time to come in, you just sleep in a different room until it arrives.

(Expandability) You can gradually add split units one room at a time when budgets allow instead of having to upgrade the whole house at one time. But planning is needed for external aesthetic reasons (see cons).



Cons:
(Condensate draining). If you have multiple minisplits installed in your home, you need to figure out a good way to drain the condensate from multiple systems - preferably into a home drain plumbing with proper p-trap. Letting it just drain into your yard can over time cause a muddy mess.

(Aesthetics) If you do not plan your installs properly, having multiple systems installed by multiple installers in multiple configurations can result in an eyesore. See this photo for an extreme example https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/jul/17/air-conditioning-curbs-could-save-years-worth-of-emissions-study

(Air filtration) With traditional systems, you can buy some really nice 3M Filtrete air filters that filters out really fine particles - some even claim bacteria... no such thing with minisplits unfortunately. Their washable reusable filters are typically fairly large mesh design which only filters out larger dust and lint particles.

comment:
This is an opinion piece not a concrete pro/con video ( in my opinion )

You didn't mention the most important part and that's running costs are substantially less compared to central air.

If you have solar ( or if you don't ) this is tons cheaper to run year round. And I am at a loss how you say it's more expensive. I was quoted $15k for central air ( with 5 year old new duct work ) from a "HVAC Pro" in my area.

FWIW I installed a 5 zone Fujitsu mini split in connection with local electricians and HVAC tech for less the $5500 total. All I did was the labor of installing the pad / condenser / line sets and hung the wall units. It took me about 8 hours by myself to do the install and the next day the lines were charged and running. All permitted and about 1/3rd the cost of what the pro's were trying to sell me on.

He also tried to sway me to going central air based on his opinion that split systems were inferior. A year later and I'm glad I went with my gut.

comment: I was thinking of replacing my homes forced air oil furnace with a traditional air conditioner like you suggested. The ducting is already there right so why not? I ran into some issues. Namely, the circuit required would end up with me having to upgrade my service. I only have 120A service currently and would have to go for 200 because of the backup electric heater that needs to be installed for the new unit. This significantly changed the equation for me and in the end I left the furnace but added a mini split for my main floor which has been a very solid unit thus far....5 years now. It cools well in the summer and does a great job heating the place in the winter up here in Canada....NS to be exact.

comment:
I recently test drove a 22' JCW it's so much fun to drive but there was one thing that was annoying with the Manual Transmission. The rev hang (not to be confused with rev-match) on these are amongst the worst i've encountered on any car [regardless of Sport or Mid mode]! It makes it impossible to shift up quickly (you can actually see it in the video at 16:10 and 16:14 ). It looks like bad shifting, but it's not; the revs are just not dropping fast enough when shifting up [it literally takes 1.5 seconds until it drops]. MINI did this on purpose to meet emission standards. Upon research as of May 2023, no one has figured out how to disable it that I know of. [Seriously, test drive a new Miata ND and you'll see how quickly you can shift in that due to little to no rev-hang]

I'm sure it just takes some getting use to, to shift "smoothly". I also test drove it with the new 8speed Auto and it's quick, however not as engaging. So even with rev-hang, i'm still going to purchase the manual.

comment: I put a full set of .75" Bora spacers on my 2015 tacoma to give her an aggressive stance. There was some minimal rubbing on the back of the front fender wells, but it was an easy fix with some garden sheers. I'm sure I'll be doing some more trimming in the future, so we'll see. The cornering is where I notice it the most, the lower center of gravity helps out a lot in keeping my truck more level when cornering. I'm running a 2" lift with 285 75 R17 BFGoodrich mud terrains. I'd highly recommend the Bora spacers. I'm a machinist and I was picking apart those spacers down to the last detail of noticing they run a faster feed on the back of the spacers to help prevent them from fusing to the hub. Solid machining for sure.

comment:
Had one in 1964. Paid ¬£200. De Luxe version, previous owner had stuck a strip of varnished wood down each side. Worked very well, apart from rain causing problems for the distributor, solved by encasing it in a rubber glove and wiper arms which had a habit of loosening on the spindles and dropping flat to sweep rain from the bonnet. A piece of shag pile carpet on the load floor cut down road noise. Had lots of minis. 89ARP - that number would be worth something nowadays. On G800 tyres could hurl round tight bends when posher car drivers behind went white knuckled and wished they‚Äôd worn the brown trousers. Robert Mark Police Chief said they definitely contributed to Road Safety. Dunno about that, just made you drive it faster.
I read that the prototype mini had the engine installed the other way around, with manifold to the front and distributor to the back. Went 90mph on test but turning the other way to make for easier maintenance meant installing an idler gear which reduced the speed by 15mph. Greatest ever innovation by Alec Issigonis as followed by most manufacturers who adopted fwd. Although CItroen thought of it first.

comment:
That's one posh mini van. When I was a student my Dad provided one for me to drive. It was a 'V' plate (1979) and I'm pretty sure it didn't have those flashy triple-dials; just the standard single speedo. Even being from 1979 it still had the sliding windows, basic grill and static seat-belts. But it was usable transport.... until I hit a tree. Fortunately the van was already on its side BEFORE hitting the tree so the force was spread across the whole of the front end, otherwise the outcome may have been different!
Earlier in life, in the late sixties, we had a mini van as my dad's work van which doubled as our family car. It must have had a seat in the back, but even with three boys there was no argument about who had to sit in the middle because there were no windows to look out of anyway! After the mini we progressed to the relative luxury of a Bedford HA van.

comment: You put copper behind a wall and it will rot your wall out with moisture dripping inside the wall. What I heard the best option for coiling up extra line set is to do it horizontally. comment:
Nice yacht. Priced competitively. If I may...a word of caution when it comes to the classic diesel engine belief they are just broken in if the hours seem low. As you are probably very aware, Marine diesel engines are an engine parts & repair shops dream come true. With Mann diesels, it's like hitting the lottery.

Beware, those Mann V-12s are not cheap to maintain. If you skip maintenance, it WILL burn your wallet later. Once they pass 6,000+ hours, they will eventually vapourize your wallet to the sea floor if they are not run frequently. At 3,500 hrs over 12 years, that's an average of 291 hrs / yr. That's pretty good. It really depends under what load conditions they've been run.

These engines need to be run at ¬æ load or more at least once every 60 days, if they are going to make it past 5,000 hrs. Depending on the specific model, the Time Before Overhaul (TBO) can vary between 5,000 and 18,000 hrs and annual Max load hrs. The turbos can be finicky. These particular engines are no longer in production. The Block and bottom end are still in production. But the cylinder heads, fuel injection and valve train have all been replaced and are not backwards compatible.

Getting parts as time goes by should be okay. Mann support is pretty good, but pricey. 100% more than Cats or Cummins.

Overhauling these engines will cost a small fortune. At 3,500 hrs, they are mature engines and in imo, well past break-in. üòé

The general rule of thumb with Mann diesels, the higher the max rated HP at high RPM, the lower the TBO will be. The top of the line Mann 1,600 HP 24 liter V-12 at 1,800 max RPM has a TBO of 18,000 hrs. While a same rated HP model that runs at 2,300 RPM has a TBO of 5,000.

Your TBO will vary based on operator management. üôÉ

comment: The gal is beautiful.  The boat.  Well, its a nice boat with proper sized and robust hand railing the way it should be.  The full sized appliances in then kitchen and laundry are smart and far better than the compact undersized and expensive boat applicances usually found on vessels.  Excellent job on the appliances.  The front deck is very odd and wasted space with two lounge pads on a slanted surface which I find awkward and just plainly weird.  Lastly the boat has entirely way too many shitters on board.  The upper shitter is nice and only two full sized bathrooms are needed in the quarters below.  Way to many shitters and wasted space and that reptile style countertops and accents are not good IMO.  Its a really nice boat in many ways but the excessive bathrooms and odd front deck really bother me.

comment: Oooh, LOVE this more traditional, trawler style, boaty, yacht!!  A true live aboard cruiser.  This reminds me  of the Fleming Yachts line of cruisers.  Bummer the flybridge deck is a little tight, but like you said, there is potential on the foredeck for additional seating.  The kitchen on this boat is the bomb and there are advantages to having it separated from living areas; number one being, when you are entertaining, kitchen clutter is out of the line of view from the salon and dining room.  That's is a feature l dislike, even in land homes; to walk in the front door and the first thing you see is the kitchen sink!  Truly, I was basking in ALL the beautiful woodwork, throughout this gem!  Please, please, if you ever get the opportunity to walk thru a Fleming; I would be in heaven!!

comment:
Johnny, I‚Äôm not sure anyone has mentioned it in the comments but there‚Äôs a chance that 90‚Äôs cooper is the most special of that era as it‚Äôs the rarest RSP cooper! The Rover Special Products cooper was the first batch that were produced to test the market. Not sure how many were made but they were snapped up and led to the rest being made.
I know of two tell tale signs that are unique to an RSP cooper: one is the plastic rectangle extension piece of the air filter box, going across the rocker cover (which is what triggered me to comment) and the other is the bolt hols in the wheels ‚Äòline up‚Äô with the spokes (after this the holes line up with the gap in the spokes).

Edit: well the wheels are not RSP wheels but still may be an RSP cooper??

comment:
Can easily tell the carb cars from SPI/MPI by the air filter housing and visible dashpot damper screwed into the top of the carb. That one looks like a 1 1/2 or 1 3/4 SU, think my last one on a 1340cc was 1 3/4 HIF.

They run like a bag of spanners when the dashpot runs out of oil, I had to pull over fairly often to refill mine on the last one I had. Was always a worry when out in the middle of nowhere on a dark country lane it starts running rough, was usually the dashpot damper or a dying coil.

I NEED another classic mini, I just haven't got the funds. One day.

Great episode.

comment:
Hi Keith, Greetings from Australia.. I had the same problem with a windscreen rubber which I bought from Mini Sport Australia.
I assume this was sourced from a British manufacturer, but after battling with it for an hour, I gave up and got a windscreen specialist to do the job.
I wasn't surprised to see that he had the same problem. We gave up and he ordered a rubber from an Australian manufacturer.
This was much more pliable and the screen was in within minutes.
I didn't,but I hope you can contact Mini Spares ,to let them know about your dissatisfaction with their product.

comment: This car was from Ireland, the regestration was 69 C 25 .   This is how it works the number 69 represents the year 1969, the letter C  represents the area where the car was registered, County Cork, also the place where Henry Ford built his first factory outside the USA, The number 25, is the number of imports that were registered at that time, into Ireland. This mini is a left hand drive, it is not a true Irish mini, we drive Right hand drive, just like the UK and Australia, so this mini was imported into ireland from a warmer climate, as Irish cars are prone to rust from our beautiful Irish weather,  nice car uncle RICHIE.

comment:
Well, you got a little more than you might think. The body is about 1969 (external door hinges and sliding windows, with hydraulic suspension), but the engine is MUCH more modern.
The reinforcement ribs on the engine block tell me that the engine is what they call an A+ engine, probably 1275cc (could be 998cc). But it also seems to have an aluminum head rather than the normal iron lump. Plus the ARP head studs are a give away. And a more modern distributor with electronic ignition. The Weber carb setup is definitely somebody's project.

The chrome trim around the door windows say it's either a Cooper or someone went through a lot of effort to find the nice trim bits. The 1000 on the back says that that would be a 998 Cooper that had an engine swap.

Properly sorted, you could get some good profit reselling that car.

comment:
I would suggest at the very least you pull the oil pan and clean the sludge out of that. Then put in a fresh fill of motor oil, drive it for 10-15 minutes and change it. After that double the time driving, change it again and repeat until the oil you drain out is perfectly clean. That should take 5-10 oil changes based on the sludge you found in the gas tank. Also as pointed out turn the choke off, you'll pick up at least 15 horsepower.

Note, transmission oil change would also be a good idea. Some good news on that front is that transmission oil typically has a long shelf life so just a simple change should do it unless you find blobs of sludge blocking the drain opening. If it's all sludged up fill it to the top with kerosene and let it sit for at least a week or two. Then drain it all out and leave the drain plug out for the last bit of congealed crud to dribble out. Then a fresh fill of the correct gear oil (look it up because even in the 60's there was a bit of variety in gear oils). Do not assume it takes straight 90W because I've already made that mistake and totaled a final drive on a shaft drive Honda motorcycle.

As for what to do with the car once you have it road worthy. Do be a damned idiot. It's a rare and collectable automobile, so do your best to restore it to it's original condition or just simply fix all the faults like that door hinge and clean and recondition the interior. Do NOT do something like shoehorning a WRX engine into it, or converting it to be electric, leave as a simple economical little car that was actually rather fun to drive.

PS: if you want something to destroy by converting to electric or jamming in a WRX powertrain to it to a car worthy of that level of disrespect, such as a Ford Pinto or Pontiac Aztec.

comment:
Dude, you might want to check your vehicle identification plate, or bodywork for cut-and-shut welds. That rear end is not 1969 Cooper. I've owned and raced a 1969 MKII Cooper S and several other standard Minis and can assure you of six things. First, a '69 Cooper always has two fuel tanks and two filler caps, one in either side. Second, it is exceedingly rare to find a genuine Cooper with rectangular tail lights. Cooper was a modification workshop, similar to Shelby in the US. They worked with bodies bought in bulk and all of the 69 Coopers I have encountered first hand have had the original round edge tail lights. I have seen one or two online since watching your video with rectangular lights, but along with the missing Cooper fuel tank, I would suggest this may be a modified standard Mini.
Third, no one in their right mind replaces the Original twin SU carbs on a car that valuable. The manifolds alone command stupid prices online.
Fourth, Coopers by 69 had front disc brakes. They were well-proven rally and race cars and built for competition. Cooper was a racing modification workshop.
Fifth, the 1000 badge on the rear is the last straw. The MK. II Cooper ran the very famous 1275cc engine, never a 1000.
Sixth, (sorry about the edits, I keep finding new things wrong with the Cooper providence), Coopers were fitted with electric fuel pumps, not mechanical ones as the twin SU carbs were thirstier than the original fuel pumps could supply.
A genuine Cooper's chassis number may be ascertained as follows:
YG2S4 followed by an individual body number i.e. 1234 (YG2S4 1234)¬†This number must also be stamped into the radiator shroud¬† Some cars also have the build number (501 less than the body number) stamped into the gutter on the passenger side of the scuttle panel.
Similarly, the engine number must fall into this range:
9FXEY followed by and individual engine number.
My suspicions may prove unfounded, but based just on the absence of the Cooper second filler cap and associated bodywork, I would suggest you check the engine and chassis numbers as explained above.
As for the nasty fuel, replace all of your rubber lines. If any ethanol blended fuel has been used in rubber lines, it is likely long disuse has caused the inner rubber to perish and travel into your filter as debris. Never use anything but unleaded in your Mini. They were built to run on 100+ octane leaded fuel. Your motor looks younger than a genuine Cooper 1275 and may have hardened valve seats to use unleaded, but if it's around 1970-1972 vintage British supplied, you may want to consider valve saver fluid in your fuel.

comment:
Unfortunately this mini does not have orginal engine installed (this is probably the reason it was cheap)
12:41 Shows "WFM 1024" on the engine block. This is a much newer A-series+ from a 1275. Incidently you can also see above the alternator the blank spot on the block where someone has removed the engine identification plate (hmmmmmm)
17:21 shows the vin number starts with KA256 which confirms that the rest of the car it is indeed a "Morris Mini Cooper Mk II (998) 67-69 "
However there are also a few other things that are not orginal, the front Cooper badge, the wooden cooper steering wheel and the black wheel arches... I am sure a real mini nerd would spot other stuff. So in summary what you have is a 998cc mini with a much newer 1275 engine installed (this may explain the work done on the brakes). Hope this helps

comment:
stick a honda civic engine in it and a custom subframe they are made in the states or just do a super tune on the old engine stage four-cylinder head bigger camshaft higher lift better pistons and con rod you can even put a turbo on the old engine or a supercharger from a BMW mini big bore exhaust used to do many in my younger days when I was learning my craft you can even put a cambelt on instead of the old timing chain makes it more tuneable there are just so many parts for them so you could go the honda way or build the original me myself I would rebuild the original and quadruple the power easy here in the UK we can buy a fuel pump for as little as 13 pounds if you shop around parts are still dirt cheap you can buy just about anybody panel you want even a complete shell if you want one but are not original some panels you can get original-like wings but they are four times the price I owned three when I was young 17 to 22 years old super them all up had a load of fun with them and sold them for six times as much some even more its a great little car for messing about with and so many parts to choose from over her there are so many racing clubs with just minis still they are as popular as ever plus some are making there's electric and drag racing them as they are so quick but are only two seaters now as the back is full of batterys
so have fun rich from a retired fully qualified mechanic in light and heavy vehicles and PSV: (busses and coaches) I did the lot my last job was working for the royal automobile club for fifteen years RAC for short had a great time there would still be there if it wasn't for an accident which left me disabled but hey that's life I got a full pension of them as they are a great company to work for well they were when I was there so good to look rich it will be interesting to see what you decide I will be watching with bated breath all the best from john from Rugby UK.

comment:
I had a 1961 Morris Mini 850 super delux (heater as standard).
These cars were rubbish. Rusty after 3 years and huge money pits.
The top of the range cooper s was slow by todays standards. My 1.2 automatic Picanto is quicker!
The carb was a delight to work on and the tappet adjustment a welcome annual job.
And please move the speedo to behind the steering wheel. That was a very popular mod.
Oh the steering wheel is on the wrong side!!! And you have extra crap under the bonnet for USA emission regs.

comment:
So many suggestions for you! I have built 3 of these, they are such great cars to work on!

Get a SU 1.5 inch carb to go on there (that weber is way too big for the small cc engine) Also look at getting some electric distributor parts (removes the contact breaker points) maybe even look at fully electric ignition running from a retrofit crank sensor and pickup.

would be happy to help you source any parts from here in the UK (London)

comment: I'd say go electric, it'll be much quicker. But, you'll lose that clattering sewing machine sound, very V.W.  sounding. I remember researching transfer cases and I do believe that there is something available that will turn it into a two gear, forward and reverse, car. I think that the original gearbox would be much more entertaining and probably easier on an electric motor, lowering r.p.m.s at higher speeds. Anyhow, a few friends had them in the '80s that souped them up for track racing. Even lowered them with stiffer suspension and wider tires. They were very fast and hilarious to get in and out of being so low to the ground. I've always wanted one and have seen them imported from Japan for just under $10K and in very nice aesthetic condition. Mechanically? I wouldn't know.

comment: I'm in the UK, the classic Mini was a rite of passage for any classic car nut, not so anymore, they are now very expensive to buy.  That amount of gunk - that car had not started since 2012.  The A-series in that is a good engine and very easy to work on, that one looks like it's had a rebuild and mods already.  My brother and I stripped and rebuilt one in a few weeks as our first ever project car.  I would say, change the oil, filter and flametraps.  The gearbox did sound healthy and if the changes are precise, you are in a good place.  The gearbox and engine share the same oil, the gearbox is actually in the sump.  As for spares, get them from the UK and get them shipped, there is a huge number of owners and spares availability is very good.  The 'chassis' is two subframes, it's vital they are good AND the sills are okay, again vital as the car is held together by those.  You have to restore it, parts are cheap (if sourced correctly).  The expensive parts are the interior and brightwork and they looked okay.  Restored, they are worth a fortune, especially Coopers. A Cooper 1000 in restored and excellent condition is easily ¬£30,000 now.  Good luck.  Liked and subbed.

comment: Hey Rich, congrats on your awesome purchase from Montreal, Canada. When I was a teenager, my Dad was a Mini freak and we had FIVE of them lined up in our driveway. Mine was a 1979 Mini 1000, my sister's was a 1980 Mini 1000, my Dad had a 1968 Mini 1000 AUTOMATIC (quite rare) and a 1967 Mini Moke 850, and we had a sacrificial parts car. We worked on our own cars exclusively. That was in the era when you didn't have to be a computer programmer to figure out why your car wasn't starting. All this to say, if you run into problems or have questions, please PM me. And BTW, do yourself a favour a source a copy of David Vizard's seminal book Tuning The A-Series Engine. Presuming you aren't going to swap the A-series out of your car, you need to read his book. Again, all the best, and thanks for the very fun channel.

comment: Car is in very good condition for a 1969, but there are many strange things, has correct hydrolastic suspension, but many later parts, later windscreen wiper motor, mechanical fuel pump, non original carburettor, in 1969 an electrical SU pump would have been fitted, badge on car says 1000, but that appears to be a larger bore engine, probably 1275, in 69 a dynamo (positive earth) would have been fitted, this car has an alternator (negative earth). Probably many other alterations  too, but sorted, this should be an excellent car and worth a fair bit. I would not convert it to electric. I have a 1962 Mini, a 1969 Mini 1000, same colour as yours, and a 1969 Riley Elf Mini.

comment:
Thats a Down draught webber carburettor. Should be good on that 1275cc engine.

I recommend fitting a Single 1+3/4" Hiff44 Su carburettor
i got a 1+1/4 Su on my 850cc engine. On my 1965 mk1 Austin mini.
And always had a Hiff44 su on my 1400cc (overbored 1275)

Also that is a hydrolastic suspension. A total nightmare to work with but is easy enough to convert to the rubber type or better still coils or coilovers. Changing that itself is a great problem solver also.

So glad you love driving it. They really are brilliant cars. I have had minis since 2005. And never look back with any regrets. They always make me smile. And make me soo proud when we (the mini and myself as i class them as my very own family i love them that much) get to a destination. And always makes me look back and smile when parked up anywhere purely out of pride for them.

As for the plans. Try to keep it as original as possible. I myself have 4 of them but i always prefer my Mk1 to drive as i love the smell and sounds it makes. It simply being a 1965 car. Its something some people love to pay for when they have restored and modified them and them miss that kind of thing.
My main project i have a 1400cc A-series engine all modified up and runs great but plan on putting a Nio EV motor in someday.
But having more than one is where the fun really starts. Especially having a mk1 as that is staying an original 850cc With a long gearstick.

I also thank you for giving me the motivation to get one of my minis sorted.
If you need any advice. Please message us on Facebook im on there as "Tayan Dylor" also feel free to check out my two minis also on Facebook as "mark-one themini" and "thunderbirdii themini" üòâüëç
And welcome to the classic mini community.

comment: The classic Mini Cooper runs just shy of  100MPH...wanna go much faster? Don't bother with building-up with such an old design. Pull the transverse engine/transaxle assembly...measure out just how much room you have, & drop-in  something  FWD built by Honda. Since  the old engine is heavy cast iron, weight won't be an issue. The original had  72 HP, a bone stock Honda engine starts at 100 HP & goes up from there. The ONLY thing that will have to be carefully crafted is the two front drive axles....150 HP will be easy...and parts will be far cheaper...Hell, you sell the original engine/transmission assembly & wind up ahead of the game...& have yourself a tiny rocketship to boot?

comment:
Rich - as a UK fellow mini owner I approve of your classic Mini - of all the cars I've driven a classic mini is just SO much fun.
$5,000 for a '69 cooper......... WHAT A DEAL! That is a ¬£15k++ <$20k> car in the UK even in that condition and worth around ¬£35-55,000 restored.
Electrified classic minis are going to be a big deal in the future and we are starting to see some in the UK now.
For anyone who doesn't know, PROPERLY set up with good suspension these cars out handle most of the stuff on the road and truly are 'road legal go carts'. Standard spec engines are anywhere from 33-90BHP as standard but people regularly mod the engines to 100-130BHP which is a LOT of power in something this size. Crazy people put diffent engines in and I've seen one claimed around 600BHP which is well into widowmaker terratory. People are now starting to do electric conversions on them here and someone is building a Tesla based one expected to hit around 300BHP which in a mini is enough to get to the moon in it. In your case I guess I'd go the electric route and make sure to upgrade suspension and brakes. Really excited to follow this story!

comment: It's pretty obvious that has not run in years. It has the wrong carb, should have twin Su's on it. The fuel pipe coming through the floor is has it is meant to be with no grommet. There should be all rubber hose until it meets the fuel pump then rubber from the pump to the metal fuel pipe where it starts at the at the edge of the floor.. At 13:47 there is a metal bracket to the left of your little finger, 2 bolts holding it. That is for the electric fuel pump to bolt on to and i'm sure it should have that. You need to look for fuel pump wiring at the rear of the tank to confirm or not.. The part you thought was a fuel filter is a mechanical fuel pump.

comment: Now that you own a mini, here are things you need to know. At the front, we have the bonnet and mudguards. At the rear, we have the boot. Under the bonnet, we have the donk with its carby. You are not allowed to run over a damp sponge as it will throw up water all over your Lucas electrics and it will die, small puddles are totally out of the question. You will find your gearbox inside the engines oil pan sharing the same oil. Do not forget to use the manual choke when starting. Have a lot of fun, I did.

comment:
My first three cars were minis. I just loved them for their go kart handling. There are twin carb setups but a Honda swap is way more power. Everybody used to make brackets to move the front seat pivots back a couple of inches to get your knees down lower. Then another bracket to lower the steering shaft lower for a more sporting driving position. If you keep the original engine the Lucas ignition must go, a dog lifting it‚Äôs leg will be too much humidity and the car won‚Äôt start. I converted to fully electronic ignition and that was back in 1974. An electric conversion would be cool too and probably more reliable.
I used to impress my friends by reving the crap out of the engine and dumping the clutch in reverse to do donuts. That led to breaking many front u joints.

comment: The Taylor 314ce - v class is over ¬£2000 here in the UK and I simply dont understand how Taylor can justify such a price for a guitar that is mass manufactured, and has a laminated (Taylor call it 'layered'') back and sides, especially when compared to similar, totally hand made, all solid wood guitars from Furch, Eastman and Dovina. I have an all solid Eastman AC 522CE, which simply blows the Taylor out of the water, in every respect, and cost me ¬£600 less than the Taylor.  And, before someone responds by saying the heritage brands retain their value better than the newer Furch, Eastman etc brands, I dont buy guitars to trade them in or sell them on, so resale value means nothing to me. For me ,its all about the sound and build quality of the instrument and ensuring I get the best possible value for my spend.

comment: I've really been enjoying your videos.  They have made me actually want to have a classic Mini of my own.  But I wanted to mention something about torque wrenches.  When tightening, place your hand on the GRIP ONLY.  The wrench measures the torque by sensing the bend in the entire handle. If you grip it below the handle or add an extension bar for more leverage, you will get a false torque reading.  Great job on the videos!
